The Australian Democrats argue that the government has attempted to bribe the community and the Senate by promising to implement a world-class consumer framework in return for the agreement to sell off one-third of Telstra. To this end, they promised to introduce consumer safeguards which estab lish mandatory service levels in a number of areas on the condition that Telstra is sold. Apart from the fact that this is a fairly obvious admission that privatisation by itself is not going to deliver the right sorts of outcomes and that some level of regulation is necessary, the fact is that legislating for enhanced consumer protection has nothing to do with who actually owns Telstra.

By incorporating both the consumer safeguards and the sale provisions in the one bill, the government is effectively trying to force an all or nothing decision: either you vote for the sale of one-third of Telstra and you get enhanced consumer protection or you oppose the sale and with it you lose the universally desired consumer safeguards. Yet these are unrelated issues and there is simply no reason why they have to be bundled together in the same bill.

The Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill currently before the Senate is essentially composed of two unrelated sections, each amending a different act. The amendments to the Telstra Corporation Act concern the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra while the amendments to the Telecommunications Act seek to enhance consumer protection through the introduction of a customer service guarantee. For this reason, the Australian Democrats, in referring the Telstra bill to the Environment, Recreation, Communication and the Arts References Committee for inquiry, asked the committee to consider whether or not this bill should be split into two or more parts.

It was clear that many of those who made submissions to the inquiry believed that the issues are unrelated. This is highlighted by the fact that most of the submissions received were opposed to the privatisation aspects of the bill but strongly favoured the passage of the consumer safeguards. Even some of those in favour of the sale could see no virtue in having the two issues tied together. In light of the widespread opposition to the sale, they could see that dividing the bill would largely guarantee passage of consumer protection legislation which they, along with virtually all other consumers, would like to see implemented as soon as possible. Therefore, on the basis of the evidence provided, the committee concluded that the bill should be divided into two bills—one concerning the sale and one dealing with the customer service guarantee.

Dividing the bill into two separate pieces of legislation will give the Senate the opportunity to consider these matters independently. Most importantly, it will enable the Senate to vote independently upon them. The proposed consumer safeguards are to apply irrespective of whether Telstra is publicly or privately owned. As such, they need to be considered on their own merit. There is no legitimate reason why they should be entwined with the debate over whether or not Telstra is sold.

Just as environment funding should be independent of the part‐privatisation of Telstra, so too should the introduction of new consumer safeguards. However, in the event that the sale bill is passed, my proposal ensures that it cannot receive royal assent until the consumer protection bill receives royal assent. This is to ensure that, in the event of the sale, consumers are not left unprotected. Any reluctance on the part of the government to divide the bill into its natural discrete components can be interpreted only as a failure to acknowledge that legislating for consumer protection is independent of the proposed sale.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the opposition to support the motion moved by Senator Lees to split the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill. This comes as a result of the work of the Senate inquiry into the sale of Telstra and the recommendation from the majority of that committee, namely the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party representatives, to split the bill. I will not quote all the sections in our report, but on pages 15, 16 and 17 I think we give very strong reasons why it is not unreasonable for the government to accept this motion to split the bill so that the issue of privatisation is separated from the issue of consumer safeguards.

PARA.BREAK: Nobody on the committee, whether they were government, Labor or Democrat members, was opposed to improving consumer safeguards. None of the evidence given to us in many hundreds of submissions was op posed to improving consumer safeguards. Even Mr Stevens, head of the department, pointed out in the hearing—this is on page 16:

SPEECH.PARA: The consumer safeguards are, in fact, contained in the Telecommunications Act and apply, regardless of whether Telstra is 100 per cent government owned or partially privatised.

The head of the department conceded that to put these consumer safeguards in you have to amend the Telecommunications Act which establishes the regulatory model for all telecommunications in Australia. That is not the act that has to be amended in principle to allow the partial privatisation of Telstra.

Therefore, we believe it is only appropriate that the bill be split and that the consumer safeguards, whether they are the universal service obligations or the customer service guarantee, be separately dealt with and separately voted on. We believe it is a very bad mixture to have to vote on the second reading and forcing people to vote on one issue, which is the privatisation issue, and secondly combined with that the issue of consumer protection.

We all support better consumer protection and no‐one has argued against that. In fact, the only evidence we have suggests that we probably should go further than what the government has proposed in amending the Telecommunications Act. We should not combine and force the vote on two quite disparate issues, one privatisation and the other consumer protection. They are in no way organically linked. They are in no way linked in principle. The privatisation issue can be dealt with quite separately.

As expressed in our support for the majority report and the committee's recommendations, the opposition believes that they should be separated. It is interesting that even Mr Horsley, the Managing Director of Australian Telecommunications Users Group (ATUG), is generally quite sympathetic towards privatisation. In his evidence he states:

Given the circumstances and the timing that we face today, we would certainly encourage the committee. . . to attempt to separate the issues of the open competition post‐1997 processes from the privatisation processes, particularly because we have the strong view that the post‐1997 processes should not be delayed. . . we are of the very strong view that the open competition post‐1997 arrangements are paramount.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the post‐1997 legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is reasonable to split. . . many people in the industry would have an unequivocal commitment to the service guarantee in a multi‐carrier environment and would want to see that in place.

The committee accepted on the evidence that we had that the bill should be split so that people can vote separately on the principle issue of privatisation and not have it confused with the issue of consumer protection. I believe all senators will be supportive of that point when they come to consider it in this debate.

Therefore we asked—and I am pleased that it was incorporated in the amendments put by Senator Lees—that it be put into the legislation that the bill be contingent on those community service obligations going through. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is supporting this proposal on the basis that we acknowledge that the committee had a specific charge to investigate this matter and recommended to the Senate that such a measure be supported. SPEECH.PARA: It is not the first time that this provision has been considered by the Senate. The advice that I have is that a proposal on 9 June 1995 concerning the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill was one occasion on which the Senate did agree to split the bill on the basis of a proposition advanced by Senator Harradine. The opposition at that time—and the Liberal government as it is now—supported the proposal.

With this bill there is no necessary connection between two very distinct elements of it, and no reason, other than cynical opportunism, for those elements ever being linked. This government has drawn together two disparate measures in an attempt to draw political support for its privatisation program. It is not necessarily because it sees those matters being inherently linked. We would like to see improved consumer protection, and we will be pursuing that under a publicly owned Telstra.

The bill amends two principal acts—the Telecommunications Act 1991 and the Telstra Corporation Act 1991. The amendments to the Telecommunications Act relate largely to the introduction of consumer service guarantees, while amendments to the Telstra Corporation Act provide for the partial sale and also, therefore, duplicate provisions in the Telecommunications Act relating to the universal service obligation. Labor's position is quite clear. We put to the Australian people our complete opposition to the sale of Telstra. We also put our concern to improve consumer protection. We believe that Senator Lees's motion will provide an opportunity for us to exercise our commitment to the Australian people on both counts. The Senate is an appropriate vehicle through which to say to this government that this is not an appropriate policy to pursue. We do not see that there should be a linkage of these two provisions in such a way as to present the Senate with a fait accompli. We believe that Senator Lees's motion requires that two new bills be listed as a single order of the day, at the same time allowing for continued discussion of the substantive Telstra bill.

We believe that we would be able to continue the debate on the substantive Telstra motion even if the proposal to divide the bill were to be carried here today. We believe that it is important that there be no attempt to sideline the sale bill but that it should be rejected. We also believe in a continued debate in connection with the consumer services provisions of the bill. The government cannot claim that this move alters the purposes and objectives of the original bill or interferes with its prerogatives in any way because both bills can be dealt with together.(Time expired)
