Let us talk about some of the arguments we have heard from those opposite. Some of the arguments opposing privatisation are absolutely and utterly ridiculous. For example, the opposition parties have claimed that the government is proposing to sell Telstra at less than its value. They have claimed that a third of Telstra is not worth between $24 billion and $27 billion as we believe. They claim that a third of Telstra should be worth over $54 billion.

How do they get to this price? They rely on the evidence of one man who came before the Senate inquiry in Townsville, Professor Quiggin. Professor Quiggin—and you would be very interested in this Mr Acting Deputy President Watson—has some very peculiar views on how you value companies.

Professor Quiggin said that when you value a company, instead of discounting the earning stream at a normal rate—at a rate which is reflective of the risk of the company and reflective of the market rate of return—you use a discount rate derived by taking the government bond rate less inflation. Professor Quiggin was advocating a couple of months ago that we should be using a discount rate of four per cent to value this company. As government bond rates have fallen further since then, I assume that he would be advocating that we use a discount rate of about 3.5 per cent.

Let us suppose that we were using a discount rate of four per cent. Following Professor Quiggin's logic, you cannot sell this company unless you are going to receive a price 25 times net earnings. There is not one company in Australia which would receive a market valuation along those lines—not one. But that is the Professor Quiggin logic, and that is the logic relied on solely by the other side when they talk about the value of Telstra.

I had my staff go through the methods of valuation used by the Labor Party when they sold the long list of assets that I have already outlined to the Senate. Did they use a discount rate of four per cent when they sold the Commonwealth Bank? Of course not. Did they use a discount rate of four per cent when they sold Qantas? Of course not. Did they use a discount rate of four per cent when they sold Australian Airlines? Of course not. They knew, when they were in government, that it was a ludicrous and absurd argument. But now that they are in opposition, not only have their principles gone out the door but their economic credentials have gone out the door—what little economic credentials they had after 13 years of mismanaging the economy.

Not once when they were in government did they pick up the phone and say, `Professor Quiggin, we're planing to privatise yet another government asset. Please tell us how to do it.' They knew that Professor Quiggin's logic was utterly false. It has never been used in one privatisation anywhere in the world. Moreover, Professor Quiggin admitted to the Senate committee when we were in Townsville that he had never participated in the privatisation of one government company: he had never acted as an adviser to a government; he had never acted as an adviser to a company. This is just academic coffee table chitchat.

Yet the people opposite are so desperate for some justification to support their prejudice that they seized on this. By the time those opposite had finished with the Senate hearings, they had almost put up Professor Quiggin for the Nobel Prize for Economics. The shame is that nobody else would vote for Professor Quiggin for the Nobel Prize for Economics.

When we got to Adelaide, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, Mr Rann, came before the committee. He said that Telstra was being undervalued and should be valued higher and that Professor Quiggin said this and that. I said to Mr Rann, `You were a member, were you not, of the cabinet that proposed to privatise South Australia's gas company?' He said, `Yes.' I said, `What was the discount rate that you proposed to use in the privatisation of the South Australian gas company?' All of sudden he got a case of the Lawrence disease; he could not remember.

I said, `Look, was it four, five, six, seven or eight per cent?' He said, `I can't remember.' I said, `Don't tell me that you sat in a cabinet meeting, decided to privatise this company, worked out the value of it and couldn't use a discount rate to do it. You must have used a discount rate.' I then said, `Why don't you take it on notice. I'm not trying to trick you. Just go away and take it on notice and then come back and tell us whether you used Quiggin's valuation method in deciding to privatise this company when you were a member of the South Australian cabinet.' We have not had an answer to that question yet, because Mr Rann knows that he did not use Professor Quiggin's valuation method. He knows that not one sane, reputable government in Australia would use Professor Quiggin's valuation method.

It does not matter when you are in opposition and you are the Labor Party, because sanity goes out the door. For the Labor Party, sanity and good economic management go out the door when they are on the other side of the chamber. They are not concerned about the good government of this country. They are only concerned with trying to whip up fear, hatred and loathing for the government. That is all that this is about. It is a cynical, base exercise in scaring the Australian population witless. That is what this is all about.

BREAK.PARA: That gets me on to some of the outrageous claims that we have heard the Labor Party and the Democrats make in regional Australia. They claim that the partial privatisation of Telstra is opposed in regional Australia. To check out these claims, I actually made an effort to travel around three western Queensland towns, just two weeks ago, to talk about the partial privatisation of Telstra. It was amazing. If you believed the people opposite, the view in the bush is that Telstra should not be subject to partial privatisation. The truth is that the bush is fed up with the service they get from Telstra. To go out into the bush and say, `Telstra is a fine Australian company and should be kept as it is,' does not attract enormous support. In fact, it attracts howls of derision.

For the benefit of honourable senators who do not live outside the capital cities, let me explain why that is so. I live in Cairns, which is not exactly Muttaburra, Cunnamulla or Oodnadatta, but it is regional Australia. When I pick up my telephone and dial Kairi on the other side of the mountain from where I live—it is a distance of about five to 10 miles as the crow flies—I pay STD call rates even though it is within the same dialling area. I do not have to dial the STD prefix, but I still have to pay STD rates.

If I am in Atherton and I phone Kairi, I have to pay for a timed call. It is a local call but it is a timed call. Similarly, across the vast bulk of the Australian continent and in your good state of Tasmania, Mr Acting Deputy President, this is the case. Outside the capital cities, timed local calls are the norm. And the people in the bush know that they are subsidising the untimed local calls in the city. They know that Telstra is woefully inefficient and they will do anything to make Telstra more efficient. They accept the fact that in this legislation there are still going to be untimed local calls for the city. But what they want to achieve is a reduction in the cost of the calls for them.

To understand the amount of subsidy that comes out of the bush for the city, you have to understand that it was given in evidence to our committee that in fact the average cost to Telstra of providing an STD call around Australia at any time varies between 3c and 6c a minute. And yet the average call charges are often between 20c and 40c a minute. So there is an enormous profit there but it is going to subsidise the loss making operations in some of the gentler suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane.

In other words, the bush is cross‐subsidising the city and the bush is paying through those outrageous timed calls for the inefficiency of Telstra. Partial privatisation is designed to make Telstra more efficient so that the bush will not be subsidising the inefficiency but will be getting a decent go. After all, when you see what primary producers and small businesses in the bush have had to do to reduce their costs it is not unreasonable to expect Telstra to reduce its costs as well.

Then we come to the other great furphy: that if we have partial privatisation of Telstra what will happen is that thousands of people in the bush will lose their jobs. But, of course, the truth is that this government is proposing for the first time since telephones were installed in the bush to give people in the bush the same opportunity to get high quality telecommunications as people in the city because we are going to accelerate the roll‐out of the 64‐kilobyte link to just about every country town in this nation. We are taking about the roll‐out of high quality fibre‐optic cable right around this country. So rather than decreasing the employment in telecommunications in the bush, we will increase the number of people employed in the telecommunications industry in the bush over the next couple of years. Of course, that was something that those opposite did not want to know about in their blind prejudice in reading this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the facts. The jobs are going to go. We know they are going to go because of the privatisation.
—That was something those opposite did not want to know about when it came to the debate. They did not want to know about that.
—You can't refute the facts.

—Now we have another interjection from Senator Lundy. I know Senator Lundy is not strong on logic—when she was given a set of cufflinks she thought they were used to pierce her wrists—but it would be nice, Senator Lundy, if we had just the slightest bit of reasonableness from you and your colleagues opposite.

BREAK.PARA: What we are talking about here is the facts. I know the Labor Party do not like facts in large doses. A few facts each day are more than enough to challenge their prejudices. But what we are talking about here is the facts. The facts are, as Mr McLean, who is the State Secretary of the CEPU in Queensland said, there will not be any job losses in the telecommunications industry from partial privatisation. He said that all that would happen is that people will go from working for Telstra to working for skilled engineering. He accepted, as many other did who appeared before the inquiry, that job growth in the telecommunications industry had increased at a quite substantial pace over the last four or five years and would continue to increase. In fact, the competitors to Telstra like Vodafone who came before our committee said, `Look, we can't get enough skilled technicians.'

So what is this all about? It is not about the number of people in jobs in the telecommunications industry. It would be an outright lie to say that the opposition to this was about the number of people in jobs in the telecommunications industry. This is about the number of people employed in Telstra who can be forced into a union. What terrifies the people opposite is that if these people go from working for Telstra to working for skilled engineering, as Mr McLean himself has said, they might not be cajoled or coerced or corralled into joining a union.

That is what this is all about. This is merely about maintaining the ability of the CEPU to force people against their will to join a union. It is not any sort of argument about maintaining employment levels in the telecommunications industry and it is not about maintaining the value of our telecommunications infrastructure. In fact, if we do not have the partial privatisation, if we do not have the reforms, if we do not have the efficiency, the value of our telecommunications in fact will be reduced.

It is not about any of those things; it is about the blind prejudice of those who want to maintain the ability of the CEPU to get people to join their numbers without having a choice. They know that whilst Telstra is a government instrumentality they can force people to do these things and they know that if Telstra were partially owned by the private sector, if these people were working for another company, they would not have the same coercive power. That is what this is about.

It is not about the bush. It is not about delivering decent standards of telecommunication. It is not about giving people in Oodnadatta or Cunnamulla or Muttaburra a fair go. What this is all about is maintaining a telecommunications company which is inefficient by its own admission, which does not service the bush and, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, exists to force people to join the CEPU. This is not about making Australia a better place. This is not about good economics—heaven help us if Professor Quiggin was all about good economics: this is about supporting the blind prejudice of the Labor Party which has suddenly decided to ditch every single one of their principles just because they were forced to sit on the other side of the chamber. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting for me to have this opportunity to contribute to this debate on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill after hearing the ranting diatribe from our colleague across the chamber Senator O'Chee. Australia and indeed the world are in the midst of an evolutionary phase in the development of telecommunications. The convergence between the technologies is indicative of the new approach to information services in the corporate sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The rapid advances in digital compression technology and processor capability are reshaping our expectations of the level of service that we will have available to us. Governments are confronted with fresh challenges as new and hybrid technologies emerge. The task this presents is to ensure that the public interest is served, not the interests of private corporations, as Senator O'Chee alluded to.

In Australia, the countdown to full and open competition is continuing, but the legislative framework still needs to be finalised. This whole transition is occurring at a time when technological convergence in information service and delivery is becoming a feature of telecommunications entities as they position themselves to maximise market share and subsequent profit.

How the government handles this transition will be a considerable factor for both the future viability of the Australian telecommunications industry and the quality of services available to both homes and business, whether in rural or urban areas. Both these issues present significant challenges for legislators. It is essential that we reach out and seize the opportunities that are presented to us through this period.

As I mentioned before, Senator O'Chee made a ranting contribution to this debate. Senator O'Chee spent a large percentage of his time dwelling on what Labor has done and what has happened in the past. I think this is a very telling point about the attitude of this government. Does it care about what happens next, about the future, or is it too committed and too bogged down in trying to discredit decisions that have been made previously? I say that its energies would be far better spent on the future of the telecommunications industry and its services to customers in Australia. What happens next year? What happens the year after that?

The government should get its focus right. If this government had any vision beyond the next election, it would realise that decisions made now will determine whether or not Australia continues to ride the technology wave or just falls off the back, never to catch up. A long-term view in telecommunications is crucial.

Australia is currently uniquely positioned in telecommunications in a global sense as well as in a national sense. We live in a country where our vast geography has by necessity created a dimension to our industry that is unparalleled anywhere else in the world. Australia's leading role in the development of optical fibre is one example. We have heard again this morning that it is that optical fibre roll‐out that presents a unique perspective to our industry and its development here.

Many of these strengths must be attributed to the role that Telstra has played as a publicly owned corporation. The introduction of full competition can and will be used to further this advantage, but partial privatisation or full privatisation—which we know will be the eventual outcome—is not going to have any impact on the improvement of competition. This role of Telstra as a publicly owned corporation must not be squandered or abused, and that is what this is all about. The privatisation would equate to just that.

To sell Telstra in the way that this government proposes represents the extraordinary contempt with which this government holds the people of Australia. To even attempt to sell in the period of legislative change that we are going through with telecommunications is absolutely ludicrous in the extreme. This government wants to squander one of the best opportunities that this country has had for industry development.

As a participant in the committee that inquired into this matter, I found that, not surprisingly, ideological obsession was exposed as the primary motivation for pursuing this sale. Not only is this government seemingly oblivious to the opportunities, but it is unwilling to acknowledge the damage that its agenda with respect to Telstra will inflict upon the industry.

The linking of some of the profits from the sale of Telstra to the funding of the Natural Heritage Trust programs represents the most cynical political move ever seen. It was with great mirth that I heard Senator O'Chee speak about cynicism with respect to Labor's approaches to this particular issue. The Australian community and the environmental organisations have been exposed to blackmail. Ironically, not through the Telstra inquiry, but through the inquiry into the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill, those same environmental organisations have discredited entirely the linkage and the attempt at blackmail by this government.

BREAK.PARA: It is becoming quite common knowledge that this linkage is the source of some hilarity within the government ranks. I think this says so much about the regard that this government holds for the people its represents, particularly those people who have conservation and repair of our natural environment as their primary concern. It is a slap in the face.

Given the linkage with the environment bill and the ideological motivation for the sale, what does this in turn say about the government's attitude towards the role that telecommunications play in our society? The ability to communicate and access to information are determinants of power in our society. Telstra's dominant role in telecommunications makes it a player in ensuring equity of access—the ability for everybody to use the services it provides.

In the current context the government must move decisively to ensure equity of access. Ministerial direction must be maintained if people are to be considered before profit. The broad terms of reference in the Senate inquiry into the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill allowed a wide expression of views on this matter. The range of issues explored form a solid base of information for use when decisions are taken regarding the post‐1997 regulations and, indeed, the degree of intervention that occurs in the telecommunications industry. It is crucial that this wealth of knowledge, facts and opinions brought into the public arena as a result of the Senate inquiry be used as widely and as extensively as possible. Not to do so would be a further contemptuous act by this government.

It is, however, not surprising that the government so vehemently denigrated that inquiry process. When you look at the outcomes, it becomes obvious that they anticipated there was no substance to their argument. It may be that the government never anticipated having to justify the privatisation—instead, hoping to rely on blackmail to find the cross‐bench support necessary for this bill's passage through this place. Despite the grandest efforts of this government, the only skerrick of productivity benefit that could be attributed to any privatisation of a public utility was that of a Chilean company under Pinochet's dictatorial regime, and that was a mere 1.5 per cent. They had to dig pretty deep and look far and wide to come up with that one, I can assure you.

It is significant that the primary evidence used by Telstra, by the Department of Finance and by the Department of Communications and the Arts was exposed as being fundamentally flawed. Whatever argument the government puts up on this in refuting the evidence put forward, you cannot refute the words on the papers of the studies that they use to prop up their arguments.

The evidence to which I am referring, a World Bank study, published in 1992, entitled Privatisation: The Lessons of Experience, by Kikeri and others, is not an empirical analysis of the benefits of privatisation at all—which is what the government has asserted. This report is but an appraisal of privatisation policies. It does not even attempt to analyse the improvements in services or productivity that may or may not arise as a result of privatisation.

This is even acknowledged in a later World Bank study by Galal and others, published in 1994. In this report of the 7,000 or so privatisations that have occurred, only around 2.5 per cent are in OECD countries—that is, comparable countries to Australia. In the same report research summaries of the welfare consequences of 12 privatisations are examined, of which only three are in telecommunications companies.
A further indictment of the comparative value of these studies to Telstra is an admission by the authors of the 1994 report that says:
We are less than sanguine when it comes to selection bias. Our cases are by no means a random sample of public enterprises around the world.
With regard to the 1992 report, the author offers the justification for privatisation in the following words:

. . . evidence from a wide variety of countries shows that far too many State owned enterprises have been inefficient and have incurred heavy financial losses . . . In many countries they have been an unsustainable burden on the budget and the banking system, absorbing scarce public resources.

This is hardly a description of Telstra, which is producing multibillion dollar profits this year. There is no doubt that, in the light of such flimsy evidence, the government has turned to repetitive derogation of the inquiry process and the majority report where we have proven there is no factual substance to their argument at all, despite the earnest assertions otherwise by Senator Tierney and Senator O'Chee. It has been shown that there is no substantiation and no benefit to the public or to the future of the telecommunications industry at all.

It is also quite significant that Telstra's employment levels, jobs—reminding you, of course, that the jobs issue formed the basis of the election campaign for this government back in March—would be reduced by 24,000 via a strategy exposed by my colleague Senator Carr during the course of this inquiry. So I am flabbergasted to hear Senator O'Chee's assertions here this morning that, in fact, jobs will not go. Sorry, we know they will, we have the facts—and Telstra have acknowledged that. Project Mercury represents the shedding of one-third of Telstra's employees—one-third!

It is interesting to see that downsizing of that nature has been criticised by its main proponent, Stephen Roach, a leading economist currently with Morgan Stanley. This fellow led much of the debate which promoted corporate downsizing as a means of retaining a competitive edge. Now Mr Roach has reassessed his views. I would like to share a few comments from Mr Roach with respect to this type of downsizing. He says:
. . . the former approach only hollows out companies without providing general economic growth.
In a recent Australian interview he went on to say that:
. . . if all you do is cut you will eventually be left with nothing, with no market share.
And:
. . . at the end of the day you can create wealth only if you've got a corporate sector that has its act together and takes a long term strategic view.
That long-term strategic view takes me to the next few points I would like to make.

It is quite significant that there has been a reduction in investment in hardware and infrastructure within the Telstra research laboratories, or TRL, with Telstra choosing instead to focus on information services. This is despite specific acknowledgment by Telstra management that TRL's strengths in these areas have `served Telstra, its predecessors, and the country very well'. In response to questioning in estimates as to who will take up the slack with respect to this research, Telstra believes that the manufacturers will. The manufacturers identified, of course, are Alcatel, Ericsson and Siemens and, to a lesser extent, Nortel. I think everybody knows that these are not Australian companies, although they do have significant presence here.

Since March, 44 staff from TRL have been given the punt, and another 133 jobs will be going in TRL. The vast majority of those jobs are in the professional and technical areas. This represents a 30 per cent cut to TRL—the research arm of Telstra. I think this highlights a very disturbing shift in Telstra's research and development policy and reinforces the need to ensure public accountability through the implementation of regional industry development strategies.

Another signal from Telstra is that, in their pursuit of potential private investors and their efforts in tidying up the books, they are sacrificing long-term projects. They are sacrificing long-term projects that would have positioned Telstra down the track in a position of strength, in the way that studies and investment they conducted many years ago did.

One such project that has been abandoned recently is, of course, the Gungahlin broadband project. Gungahlin is a region in the ACT; it is a new suburban area. This particular project was abandoned in its original form at about the same time—surprise, surprise—as the privatisation bill hit the lower house. A different project has since emerged to assist in the damage control that the company had to initiate to buffer themselves not only from investor backlash but from charges that, in fact, it did represent a move away from long-term research into short-term strategies with a short-term gain.

Policies of the Labor government over the last decade have generated one of the fastest OECD growth rates in the research and development investment by business as a share of GDP. However, Australia still retains one of the lowest ratios of business expenditure in research and development to GDP, at 0.7 per cent. The fact is that you need to look at those broad policy settings in the context of what is happening in Telstra with their investment in research and development and how an emphasis on privatisation can detract so wholeheartedly from long-term investment in research and development.

In commenting on the changes within TRL's resource allocation, Telstra management has acknowledged that it does demonstrate that there is a movement of the research focus into new areas, particularly in the broadband, multimedia and content areas. These were the areas that the Gungahlin broadband project in its original form was going to deliver, but somehow Telstra has found the justification to move away from that investment in hardware and infrastructure, which has really been at the backbone of their developmental and innovative areas.
With respect to this issue about research and development, there is a report entitled Australia and the Knowledge Economy, which is from the Centre for Strategic Economic Studies. It states:
. . . we conclude that there is a powerful body of evidence linking increased levels of investment in business research and development to increased exports.

So this really begs the question about the relevance of R&D investment. What is the relevance? We know that there is a significant relevance of growth generally, in terms of growth of jobs and in terms of growth of exports.

As highlighted in the majority report, this fact exposes the reduction in the 150 per cent tax concession to 125 per cent—which was a decision by this government—for the flawed policy that it really is. This conclusion demonstrates how it will have the effect of impacting directly upon the potential of exports in Australian industry generally. The same report identifies two scenarios for research and development: the first will take us to a minor increase in that ratio between business expenditure and GDP, and the second will take us to a slightly larger expenditure. Both are based on previous assessments.

So, sadly, this government has taken a backward step in their budget, with cuts to research and development across the board. Another backward step in their pursuit of privatisation of Telstra is the dampening effect that that has placed on the strategic long-term investment of that organisation. Another backward step in their blind ideological assertion is that job shedding is the only way to improve Telstra's competitive edge.

A quick snapshot of the effects of deregulation and privatisation of Telecom New Zealand provides a very useful insight as to the potential negative effects on local industry, where employment in electronic manufacturing firms fell by over 40 per cent. There is a real opportunity here to make a public asset really work for the benefit of all Australians, for Australian industry and for innovation. There is no evidence that privatisation will bring about the efficiencies and improved services claimed. Take the blinkers off. Do something practical for the people. Keep Telstra in public hands. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak very briefly today. Firstly, I will talk about the Senate inquiry and, secondly, I will touch on the link to environment funding. But I cannot ignore the attack on Professor John Quiggin by Senator O'Chee in his quite inane contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator O'Chee's contribution does merit at least a brief look at basically the three themes that he touched on. Firstly, he had a go at Professor Quiggin and, secondly, he made comments about how the only solution for rural Australia is the sale of Telstra. I will leave it to my colleague Senator John Woodley to comment. I simply wish to make the point that the only way we are going to see the significant upgrading required in rural Australia is if we keep Telstra in public hands. Thirdly, he made a comment which I find quite extraordinary, and it seemed to revolve around some spurious argument about this whole thing really being about maintaining union membership. I think that is so extraordinary it does not warrant any further comment.

But I do have to briefly look at his totally unwarranted attack on Professor Quiggin, and certainly this government's approach to Professor Quiggin depends very much on the issue. In particular, I will refer to a letter Senator John Herron wrote to the Canberra Times a year or so ago, where he said:
Dr John Quiggin's analysis of the problems underlying the health care system . . . should be heeded by all in the debate.
This is the first time that I have seen a respected academic state that the problem is "of a policy process based on fundamentally misconceived assumptions" . . .
So it obviously depends very much on whether or not Professor Quiggin supports the views of this government as to how they approach his work.

Not only is he well recognised here in Australia and applauded by those of us who are rather more interested in rational economics than economic rationalism; he also has an international reputation. Unfortunately, when he came before the Senate committee, the way he was dealt with by some of those who put questions to him left him feeling that this was not a process that was terribly responsive to the facts. In a personal statement he has since made, he says:
I have previously appeared before a number of parliamentary committees frequently presenting views critical of proposed legislation.
He gives an example of the legislative entrenchment of the One Nation tax cuts. He goes on:

Naturally enough, government members of relevant committees have disagreed with the points I have put forward, and on some occasions have done so quite forcefully. I cannot, however, recall any forum, parliamentary or otherwise, in which behaviour has been comparable to that of some government members of the present Committee. Not only was much of their discussion more characteristic of a school debating society than of a serious discussion of policy, but some of the questions I was asked amounted, in my view, to an implied attempt to impugn me in my professional capacity. On a reading of transcripts of the hearings, it appears that this behaviour was part of a consistent and concerted pattern of denigration of all witnesses who criticised any aspect of the proposed legislation.

Here we have in this chamber today Senator O'Chee continuing this pattern of behaviour. One has to ask why. I will make only one suggestion. It perhaps has something to do with the actual value that this government has put on Telstra. Of all the values we heard of during the committee process, theirs was by far the lowest at $24 billion. While Professor Quiggin put it at $54 billion, there was a range of other suggestions in between that. I can imagine that one of the reasons government senators are so sensitive to Professor Quiggin's remarks and his submission is that he has pointed out that this really is almost a fire sale—they are certainly selling at a value that is well below any really accurate assessment of what this company is really worth.

On 21 May this year, the Democrats supported the referral of the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee, of which I am the chair. The Democrats were not convinced that the government had mounted a solid case for selling off one of our most strategic and profitable business assets. On this basis, we felt that additional parliamentary scrutiny of the proposal was warranted, but so too was providing the community—at this stage left out altogether—with an opportunity to have a say. The inquiry revealed that there was no substantial empirical evidence to back up the government's assertion that the economy, consumers and the environment would benefit from the proposed sale—hence, I suspect, the sensitivity of some government senators to witnesses who came before the committee and put those views.

It became clear that the government was and is being driven by little other than sheer ideology. The committee concluded that sound economic and social policy dictates that Telstra should remain in full public ownership. Moreover, the inquiry process revealed the widespread and deep-seated opposition of the community to the government's decision to sell part, let alone all, of Telstra. This has not stopped them trying to ram this ideological agenda through this place.

BREAK.PARA: Out of sheer desperation, they have had no qualms in turning to blackmail and bribery in the hope of securing support they so desperately want and so desperately require. They have sought to blackmail the Australian people by linking the sale to the funding of their environment policy and to bribe the Australian people by predicating the introduction of a world-class consumer framework on the passage of the sale bill—hence the motion I moved this morning to attempt to split the two. Rather than winning over the community, these measures have only served, and rightly so, to further damage this government's credibility.

I will now look briefly at the Telstra-environment link. The forced choice between the sale of a public asset, like Telstra, and the protection of part of a public asset, the environment, is simply and purely blackmail. Blackmail is a strong word, but it is the only word that truly describes the false choice with which Australians have been presented. It is the only word which truly describes the strongarm tactics being used by government in its efforts to justify what is extremely poor public policy—as witnesses time and time again showed as they appeared before the Senate committee. It is the only word which truly describes the actions of a government seeking to coerce the Australian public into accepting decisions and actions which are politically, economically and environmentally irresponsible.

The very abhorrence of this link has induced a senior government adviser to speak out in even stronger terms than those that I have used. I think it is worth quoting this adviser, at length, as reported in the October edition of Scitech:

We are appalled at the lies and the deception involved with this issue, it is an exercise based on just one thing—finding a way to sell off Telstra. The linkage to the environment is just a sop, designed to cloud the Telstra sale issue and to try to blackmail other parties and the general community into accepting it.

Anybody who looks at the figures can quickly see that the Natural Heritage Trust is a blatant and cynical political fraud. There is simply no way the interest from the $1 billion supposedly to be diverted from the Telstra sale could possibly pay to rectify the enormous environment problems confronting Australia.

And those who closely follow political debate in Australia will soon see the chasm between the proposed Telstra funding and the Government's own admissions about the extent of those problems. Several senior ministers, including Senator Hill, have publicly declared that these problems are already costing us a minimum of $1.5 billion a year and are rapidly getting worse.

It is also obvious that the Government's expressed concern for the environment is not in any way matched by its actions in the recent Budget, where funding for the environment was cut, and its flat refusal to consider anything other than the Telstra sale as a means of funding its supposedly crucial Natural Heritage Trust environment program.

A lot of the opponents of the Telstra sale have long suggested the Natural Heritage Trust was a cynical political invention and a blackmail device. Some have also suggested it was the creation of Mr Robb [the Federal Director of the Liberal Party]. They have always been correct on both counts, despite the Government's continuing denials. It is time the community was told the truth—the Natural Heritage Trust is a gigantic and disgusting sham.

I stress that these comments are not my own; they are a quote from Scitech magazine. They come from a senior government adviser, someone who is rightly appalled by this government's hypocrisy, someone who is concerned enough to actually take the risk of speaking out. I praise this person for having the courage and decency to make public what this government's real agenda is.

The environment, like any other portfolio, as the Democrats have said time and time again, deserves to be funded in its own right from the federal budget. Imagine the outcry if the government were to come into this place and say, `We can't fund hospitals; we can't give any money to the states for hospitals any longer. We need to sell off Australia Post. Look, we're really sorry about it, but we are having another look at schools and universities. We think we will have to sell off yet another government asset.' The fact is that the sale of assets has no bearing—and should not have any bearing—on the government's capacity to afford current expenditure programs.

PARA.BREAK: The Treasurer (Mr Costello) knows this, and I remember many occasions when he pointed this out to the previous Labor govern ment which used asset sales to conceal budget deficits and fund recurrent expenditure programs. The importance of this cannot be overemphasised. Australians should not be misled into believing that the government will not be able to afford to meet election commitments on the environment if it does not sell part of Telstra.

BREAK.PARA: In fact, on the basis of the expert economic advice provided by economists such as Dr Allan Brown and Professor John Quiggin to the Senate committee, the government will be less likely to afford environment funding if it does sell part of Telstra. Perhaps we are now starting to see more of the reasons why Professor Quiggin receives such a hard time from a number of government senators. They really do not like the facts.

The proposed sale of one‐third of Telstra for a mere $8 billion will simply result in a massive transfer of wealth from the public sector to domestic and foreign shareholders in a privatised Telstra. Predicating the availability of funds for the environment on the sale of Telstra is clearly a very short‐sighted form of blackmail which the Senate would do well to ignore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak in this debate. I am pleased to follow Senator Lees and Senator Lundy, both of whom sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which inquired into the proposed sale of Telstra. I take this chance to say to both senators that I think the way that committee was run by the chair, and also by the majority of senators, is a great credit to the process of the Senate. I sat with the committee for a very short period, less than a day, but it was quite clear from the time I spent there and from looking at the documentation which came through that the information that the committee managed to draw to it and the evidence that it managed to elicit will be quite critical when any government, party or person makes an assessment of the pros and cons of the Telstra sale.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to say that it should not be on for honest, competent people who come before Senate committees to be treated in the way Professor John Quiggin has been treated by some government members during this process, even as late as this morning. John Quiggin has not just a reputation in Australia for his economic and academic skills; he is also someone who has been recognised internationally for the contribution he has made to economic thought and development. For him to have been dismissed and attacked in the way he has been by members of the government reveals one thing: they are afraid of his ideas. If they were not afraid of his ideas, they would not attack the person. By attacking the person they accentuate the fact that the ideas John Quiggin has proposed time and time again—sometimes, and quite often, swimming against the flow of economic thought—are ideas to be listened to.

When talking about political correctness, there is no area where it is more pervasive than in the economic debate. The way people attack Professor Quiggin for his unorthodox ideas, sometimes in terms of our domestic debate but also his more orthodox ideas when looking at the world economic community, is a real reflection of where political correctness stinks in this particular parliament. We have to be able to allow people to express their views and we have to be able to respect them. We should not be allowed to criticise them in the personal way that a prominent and eminent Australian such as John Quiggin has been criticised in this process.

As I said earlier, the Senate process has elicited a lot of information and much is on the public record. It has exposed the arguments of the government. Through this process we have seen an array of people come forward with different perspectives on the sale. We have also seen the government and its representatives examined, cross‐examined and further examined as to their arguments in their evidence. It is fair to say, as the majority of the Senate committee said quite clearly, that the arguments of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) have been exposed for their shallowness.

Unfortunately for good policy in this country, the work of the Senate committee has met a brick wall of government arrogance and ideology. Why would any rational government look at the evidence elicited by the committee and make an assessment of it and dismiss it in the arrogant, ideological way that this minister has done? Here we are speaking of the most arrogant minister in a government that is fast showing its arrogance and patrician nature to the Australian people. There is an ideological fixation driving this privatisation which I think is very unhealthy. Privatisation should not be a religion; it should be something, the role of which can be acknowledged as relevant in some circumstances and as not relevant in other circumstances.

I maintain very strongly, as I have maintained very strongly for a long time, that privatisation does have a role. But it is a role that really depends on what it is that is to be privatised in light of the state of the market and other implications of industry policy. We should not be fixed in our thinking one way or another. We should not be ideologically enjoined one way so that we cannot see that there are particular circumstances that drive us in one direction or another. The fundamental mistake the government is making here is that it is blinded by the religion of privatisation to such an extent that it is not seeing the facts through its ideological blinkers.

I have always argued that Telstra is one Australian enterprise, one Australian corporation, that we should not sell. As a country, we need to develop our sense of identity. We also need to be recognised internationally, not just for the place that we are but for what we produce. As a country, we do not have any pride in what we produce. Unless we have that, we will be floundering to find ourselves and to have the rest of the world find us.

There is no vehicle more suited to representing us in the region and in the world than a communications carrier. We need large corporations of which to be proud. We need large corporations which are ours and which can be identified as being ours. We need large corporations that have world recognition, as Telstra already has. We need large corporations which provide a vehicle for jobs—jobs through trade, through overseas contracts, through the skills developed at home because of markets tapped into overseas.

BREAK.PARA: We need flag bearers in the region, and Telstra over recent years has developed in such a way that it is most suited to do that. We have had such corporations in the private sector, but not enough of them. We might have BHP, we might have WMC but we do not have enough corporations, particularly at the smart end of the industry—the technological sector, the industry of the future. That is one reason I would not be inclined to sell Telstra. I oppose very strongly the sale of Telstra.

The other thing that I find quite offensive about this bill is that this sale, as Senator Lees has said, is part of a con job. It was a con job at the election; it is blackmail now. This whole idea of a Natural Heritage Trust has come from a government which, time and time again, whenever it is confronted with an environmental issue, takes the non‐environmental side. It takes the side that will lead, for instance, to mining in Kakadu National Park and to all sorts of negative impacts on the Great Barrier Reef.

We are not talking about a government that has any concern at all for the environment. Whether it be in protecting our natural history, logging or any other aspect of environmental concern, it is all words, no action. We even have an environment minister who has been jumped on by other industry ministers for fulfilling his legal obligations under the legislation passed by this parliament.

There is no legitimate concern by the government about the environment. At the start of the year, when they went for a walk in the forest and they took with them poor innocent souls like Alec Marr, promising the environment would be a nirvana with the sale of Telstra, some people were conned—

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor innocent soul!

—I was being kind to him, Senator Woods—I was being very kind to him. If any one should feel like an A‐class mug at the end of this process it has to be Alec Marr, someone who invested his whole reputation in supporting the Liberal government at the start of the year and someone who stands naked because every decision that this government has taken since the election has been a kick in the guts for the environment movement in our society.

BREAK.PARA: I find it offensive that an Australian icon like Telstra has been traded for environmental votes when the economics of it make it quite clear that the government would be better equipped to protect both the environment and industry were they not to sell Telstra and thereby reduce its capacity to reap tax through this great corporation.

I want to place on the record Professor John Quiggin's qualifications because I think they are important. As I said earlier, the government is attacking a person because they cannot attack his ideas. John Quiggin is a Senior Fellow of the Centre for Economic Research at ANU. In 1993 the Academy of Social Sciences awarded him their annual medal for excellence. They described him as a `major commentator on Australian economic policy, regarded as amongst the best half dozen research economists in the country'. He also works at the James Cook University in Townsville. That is the person whose ideas have been dismissed on the basis of an ideological fixation.

Do you sell? As I have said, I do not agree with the sale and I do not agree with what the government is trying to achieve. What is the gain? What is the efficiency gain, the economic gain? One of the most telling aspects of the Senate committee's report goes to that particular issue.

Much of the popular case for the privatisation of Telstra rests on a suggestion that Telstra is underperforming in public ownership. In particular, the ideologues on the other side are claiming that its cost structure, and particularly its staffing levels, are below world's best practice. They come in here, blind to the facts, blind to reality—as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has been in recent days about his ministers who cannot fill out forms—arguing one thing when the facts show another.

On 13 September, Telstra announced a profit after tax, abnormals and minority interest, of over $2.3 billion for the financial year ended 30 June 1996. On the day that these massive profits were announced the business editor Alan Kohler announced on the 7.30 Report that Telstra's unit cost per line was below the average of world telecommunication companies for the first time. Kohler commented:
They are 8% below the average of the world and they are planning now to stay there.
Kerry O'Brien asked him:
So would partial privatisation force greater efficiency on Telstra?
Kohler's response was:
Well, that's already happening. That's the point.
Such a comment from a respected local business analyst is, to me, much more persuasive than the rantings of an arrogant minister.

The point is quite fundamental: competition is critical here, not privatisation. Competition is what the previous government brought into the communications sector. Competition has lead to the advances and improvements across the board in so much of Telstra's operations, and it will be the critical feature of future improvements.

Competition is quite critical here. Competition has led to the outcomes that I have just mentioned. Ian Martin from BZW gave evidence to the Senate committee inquiring into the sale. He said, referring to Telstra's performance, that against a range of benchmarks, Telstra stacks up very well against overseas companies.

It is in every indicator you look at. Pre‐tax return on capital for Telstra is 22 per cent; world best practice is just over 20 per cent. Telstra's interest cover for 1993‐94 was 5.3 times; world best practice is over 5.5 times. Its debt ratio was 35 per cent in 1993‐94; world best practice is 35 per cent. Telstra's return on average equity in 1993‐94 was 18 per cent and world best practice is just over 17 per cent. It is in every aspect you want to look at, including credit ratings. In terms of credit ratings, Telstra's are amongst the highest of any major Australian company, and they have enabled Telstra to access low‐cost borrowing.

We are talking here about a major source of federal government revenue. We are talking here about a company which in the 1994‐95 financial year paid a dividend of $944 million. It also paid a tax of $649 million to the federal government. In 1995‐96, Telstra paid a dividend to the government of $1.638 billion. It paid tax of over $1 billion. That is $2½ billion. Telstra does not minimise tax payments.

It is worth noting, and is a sobering thought here, that any privatised Telstra is likely to minimise its tax payments substantially. Any such minimisation will place this government in a worse position to fund its environmental hopes. I only have about six minutes to go and I probably could go for a few more hours on this debate.

We are embarking upon this course for no good economic reason and no good economic outcome. We are embarking upon it for an ideological fixation of the government. If there was no competition in the marketplace, then you would have to look at the role of Telstra and how you would maximise its performance and its return to government and to the people of Australia.

You have got competition here. That has been the great advance over recent years. That was something that the previous government was quite keen to ensure. We always recognised that Telstra had a role to play not just as a source of revenue to government but also an organisation which had to be consumer friendly and was quite critical for a number of reasons in terms of the future of this society.

Industry policy cannot be divorced from the operations of Telstra. It has not been in the past; it should not be in the future. We are talking here about an organisation that spends millions and millions of dollars on its research, its development and its industry policy. We are talking about an organisation which has led the way in respect of locally produced equipment and exports overseas. If Australia is to develop a secure jobs base here for Australians living and working in this country, then we need to ensure that the sorts of inroads that Telstra has made into the communications market—and we are on the doorstep of the biggest communications market in the world—can be built on.

PARA.BREAK: The other thing that concerns me in this debate is the question of communications being the road of transport interaction be tween people and their interaction with the broader community of the future. We need to ensure into the future that all have access, not just to the telephone system but to other aspects of technology. We need to ensure that we do not draw a very clear line between those who do have access and those who do not.

BREAK.PARA: If you tap into the Internet these days, you have access to a whole host of information. The kids going through school at the moment who have got access to Internet have a major advantage over those who do not. We have to ensure that the technology is there for a universal information and communications superhighway.

We have to ensure that people living in outlying parts of Australia do not miss out. In my state of South Australia, for instance, we have to ensure that the community service obligation applies to the benefit of those country electorates which they on the other side purportedly represent and that people there do not miss out—people living in places like Coober Pedy, Thevenard and Port Augusta and outlying areas.

We also have to ensure that money is not a barrier to access to information, because that will be the new poverty line. If you cannot access the Internet, technology or the standard telephone service in a way provided cheaply by the provider and also without delay, then you will be deprived of full rights of participation in the society of the future. The minister has treated this issue with disdain. No‐one in the seventies would have argued that the universal service function had been achieved in that time. No‐one in the eighties would have argued it. No‐one in the early nineties would have argued that the universal service obligation had been achieved.

This is a minister who is insensitive to the role of Telstra as a guarantee of access to services. He is a minister who claimed that we actually achieved all we needed to achieve in terms of universal service by the seventies.

Technology has moved on in the last 25 years. Capacity has changed in terms of delivery of service and the services available to people. But Senator Alston draws the line and says everything we needed to achieve in terms of access of services was achieved in the 1970s. What arrogant disregard for the rights and the situation of ordinary Australians living in the suburbs and the country from a minister who is in charge of protecting the service to the public after and during the sale process.

He cares not one iota about the impact on revenue, he cares not one iota in terms of impact on service delivery, he cares not one iota in terms of ensuring that Australians have rights of access to the communications system of the future. He says all that needed to be achieved was achieved in the seventies. This is not the approach that good rational policy would demand.

It evidences that once again we see, on behalf of the government, another minister who is not on top of his portfolio. We see it time and time again. I think the unfortunate thing for Australia is that slowly people are waking up to the fact that when they did make a change of government on 3 March, and did take a risk, it was a pretty big risk because minister after minister is showing consistency. There is a common bond across the government. They do not understand their portfolios, they do not understand detail and they do not care about either.

This is going to be the epitaph of this government. We do not believe you when you say you would only sell one‐third of Telstra. We know you have been on the record for a long time as saying you want the whole lot sold. I do not agree with this legislation and I will vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill will inject private capital into Telstra. It will make Telstra more competitive. It will make sure that Telstra regains its community service obligations. It will pay off some $7 billion of ALP accumulated debt. It will spend $1.15 billion on a heritage trust to improve our environment. This is a bill which we should support.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of hares have been set running and a few fibs have been told. Let me put some of these to rest. Firstly, I will refer to the consequences for industry development and research. It is clear that Australian telecommunications equipment and service suppliers will not be adversely affected by the partial privatisation of Telstra. In fact, it is likely that the bill and the post‐1997 arrangements will actually stimulate the development of the telecommunications service and equipment industries.

Contrary to ALP claims, passage of the bill will not affect the government's current industry plan arrangements, which have actually proven successful in stimulating the telecommunications supplier industry. Under these arrangements, Telstra and the other carriers have to produce industry development plans that outline the basis of commercially based relationships with suppliers. That is aimed at promoting long-term strategic relationships between the carriers on the one hand and the suppliers.

The success of these arrangements to date is very clearly measurable not only for Telstra but also for its competitors, Optus and Vodafone. According to a range of sources, those plans have been responsible for encouraging carriers to source roughly 70 per cent of their equipment and software requirements locally. That averages out at about $2.8 billion every year. It is nonsense to suggest that the partial privatisation will erode the practical value of the industry plan arrangements.

This is borne out by an examination of the performance of the two currently privately owned carriers, Optus and Vodafone, under their development plans. In the 1994‐95 year, they both achieved significantly higher Australian content than Telstra. Optus got 76 per cent and Vodafone got 71 per cent compared with Telstra's 65 per cent. These figures just go to show that maintaining 100 per cent government ownership of Telstra provides no guarantee that Telstra will be more geared towards using Australian products or suppliers than if it were partially privatised. During the recent Senate inquiry, the Australian telecommunications industry association stated its belief that:

BREAK.PARA: . . . on the basis of a continuation of the present successful approach of recognising a close nexus between communications and industry policy, the partial privatisation of Telstra will not affect the Australian telecommunications industry.
The investment bankers BZW—highly regarded bankers—pointed out in that same inquiry:

Telstra as a publicly owned company should be no more or less benevolent than Telstra as a privately owned company to Australian equipment manufacturers, but rather treat them on their merits. Industry support arrangements . . . should be the same in both cases . . .
BZW also commented:

Improved efficiencies between Telstra [as a result of privatisation] may flow on to a more efficient Australian services and equipment industry, increasing its prospects for competing with overseas companies.

We believe that continuation of the industry plan arrangements, combined with open entry of carriers into the marketplace after 1997, is easily the best way to stimulate the Australian telecommunications supply industry. The ALP claimed it would not be commercially viable for Telstra to use Australian suppliers but, as Telstra itself pointed out, there is little likelihood that the commercial incentives for maintaining mutually advantageous relationships with local sourcing would in any way diminish with partial privatisation.

During the recent Senate inquiry, Telstra stated that it would continue to use Australian telecommunications suppliers after privatisation—not out of any sense of patriotic duty but because it is in its own commercial interests to do so. There are a number of reasons for why they would prefer local to overseas sourcing. They said that there are shorter supply lead times, reduced transport and handling costs because of proximity, and more timely and more cost‐effective after‐sales service.

PARA.BREAK: Telstra stated that its partnership with the supply industry, which is formalised in the development plan, is important in meeting the strategic objectives to move into new information and communication services. It also saw its links with suppliers may enable some firms to expand overseas and foster greater innovation on their part. BZW made similar com ments about two listed Australian equipment companies, AWA and ERG, stating that:

BREAK.PARA: Neither company would, in our view, be impacted by a partial privatisation of Telstra.

Let us look at Telstra's record to date. This commitment to the Australian supply industry is more than just rhetoric. Its figures for the 1994-95 plan show that, during that period, Telstra increased its spending on products and services by $794 million to $4.25 billion. Telstra traded with more than 10,000 suppliers, over 50 companies received orders of $10 million—a 25 per cent increase—and over 1,000 companies received orders of $400,000 or move. The expenditure on Australian content increased by an average of seven per cent or eight per cent over the last three years and two‐thirds of all purchases were sourced locally. Australian based suppliers received orders of $224 million for Telstra's offshore operations as $218 million was spent on research and development. Telstra's support for local manufacturing industry employs 13,000 Australians directly and another 20,000 indirectly.

What about the other carriers—Optus and Vodafone? They have also built up beneficial alliances with various suppliers under their plan. As I mentioned earlier, these two carriers, both of which are fully privately owned, utilise local suppliers for a greater percentage of their overall requirements than Telstra does.

This preference is not just restricted to current carriers. In the recent inquiry, AAP Telecommunications—one of the largest service providers which has the option of becoming a carrier after 1997—stated:
If we can buy from Australian sources, it is absolutely our preferred approach.

Neither will there be any significant impact on the post‐1997 industry plan arrangements. There will be no change to the current arrangements for industry plans. They work very well and they will be continued. It is the government's intention that such arrangements will be retained for all carriers including Telstra, Optus, Vodafone and any new carriers coming into the market, including those involved with broadband cable networks.

The draft post‐1997 package released for public comment already includes those provisions. The Telecommunications Industry Development Authority has monitored those plans and, post‐1997, the government will ensure that the plans continue to be monitored. It is the carriers' commercial operations after 1997 which will determine their purchase of local equipment and services. Expenditure levels are expected to remain high over the next year or two in particular as carriers continue to roll out their cable networks. The local carrier network is, and will continue to be, the base for the Australian telecommunications supply industry.

What about research and development? There have been all sorts of distortions put out about R&D. The bottom line is that there is no evidence that the partial privatisation of Telstra should or will reduce the expected expenditure which Telstra currently makes on research and development. In fact, there are reasons to expect that the current level will be either maintained or even increased.

Telstra, as an efficient part‐privatised provider of telecommunications services in Australia and in overseas markets, will be expected to utilise the latest and the best technology available for its commercial needs. Nobody has ever suggested that Telstra expenditure on research and development is done for altruistic reasons. It is undertaken because Telstra needs to respond to changes in technology use, consumer demands for new and better services and the new or improved technology resulting from this research that provides a very direct financial return to Telstra.

We would expect a part‐privatised Telstra to make decisions on R&D spending based on the commercial return it expected to receive on that spending, just as it does now. Decisions on how it meets its R&D needs—in-house or through contracting out—are properly made by the Telstra board and management. The Senate majority report noted that the wholly government owned Telstra currently spends some 0.5 per cent of its income on R&D. That is in comparison with the OECD average of 1.2 per cent of GDP. In fact, Telstra expenditure at 0.5 per cent of revenue is some 28 per cent below Australia's ratio of business expenditure on research and development of 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product.

As an aside, it is worth noting that the Japanese carrier, Nippon Telephone and Telegraph—NTT—spends 4.7 per cent of its revenue on R&D. I am sure that senators would be aware that NTT is in fact 37 per cent privately owned.

The 1994-95 Telecommunications Industry Development Authority report indicates that Optus, at the end of year 3, had already well exceeded its five-year R&D undertakings. The evidence is there are many wholly or partly privatised telecommunications companies and organisations around the world that spend more on research and development than Telstra. This makes it difficult to believe that a partially privatised Telstra would neglect research opportunities, when a wholly private company such as Optus is expending even more on R&D than planned. Why? Because of the direct commercial benefit from this expenditure. In the election the coalition pledged to retain the requirement for existing carriers to submit industry development plans and to expand this to all carriers post‐1997. An important part of those plans is the R&D aspect.

Let me turn to some other issues and look for a moment at the hypocrisy of the ALP. A few minutes ago we had Senator Bolkus talking about Telstra as an Australian icon, implying that we should not privatise Telstra because it is an icon. Let me ask him about those other icons such as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. A number of other companies and organisations were also privatised by the former Labor government, including Australian Airlines, the Federal Airports Corporation, AIDC, ANL, defence home loans and the Sydney to Moomba pipeline—the list is endless.

Not only that but it is clear from a number of historic recordings that the ALP wanted to privatise Telstra itself. There were different views within the ALP about how they should go. On the one hand, there was a view that they should privatise it as a whole lot. That was certainly Paul Keating's view at the time. On the other hand, there was a suggestion that they might privatise the profitable parts, and in particular people were looking at selling off the Yellow Pages. So bit by bit Telstra would have been privatised. That is an indication of the ALP's hypocrisy when it privatised everything it could lay its hands on. There was not much that actually avoided their privatising zeal when they were in government. But then suddenly after 2 March they take a holier‐than‐thou approach and say, `How dare you privatise what Senator Bolkus called an Australian icon.'

I have given some of the reasons why we need to privatise the icon. But let me also look at some of the less direct reasons, such as the impact on the environment. As the Senate would know, expenditure on the environment will rapidly increase as a result of this partial privatisation. An amount of $1.15 billion dollars will go to an environmental heritage trust called the Natural Heritage Trust. I might point out immediately that this is in addition to the current expenditure on the environment. It is not in place of and it is not an alternative source of funding. This is extra money for the environment.

What are we going to do with that $1.1 billion? An amount of $318 million will go to a revegetation initiative. This will be looking at land and water degradation in particular. An amount of $163 million will go to fixing up the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin. There are a number of farmers in that area who desperately see the need not just for themselves but for the whole of Australia for this project to be undertaken. An amount of $32 million will go towards a national land and water resources audit and $80 million will be allocated to preserve biodiversity. On top of that, an amount of $300 million will be kept in trust in perpetuity. It is a trust that will be used for a number of environmental projects, not just for us but for future generations. This is a very far-sighted, outreaching program.

At the end of that, there is still another $7 billion or thereabouts which will be used to retire debt—to pay off debt accumulated by the Labor Party. How on earth can the Labor Party rail against getting rid of the debt that they single-handedly—and single-mindedly, I might add—managed to raise?

Concerns have been raised by the ALP and the Democrats about the role of Telstra employees. My phones and the phones of many other members and senators have been running hot with calls from Telstra employees who wanted to participate in this partial privatisation. Up to two per cent of the float will be allocated to Telstra employees. This is another way of involving Telstra employees in their own company, of enhancing the pride which many of them already have in their company and of involving them in the process of running Telstra and making it more competitive than it is at present.

The spectre of foreign ownership has been raised as a scare campaign of the sort that we are used to from the other side. They have been saying that Telstra will be taken over by foreign moguls who are tucked away in overseas countries and have no concern about the future of Australia. The facts put the lie to this sort of comment. Some 1.667 per cent, a minuscule amount, of Telstra will be allowed to be in foreign hands.

Essentially, what will happen will be that the ownership of Telstra will remain in Australia. Australian mums and dads and employees and Australian companies will actually participate in the float of a third of Telstra. In addition, the chairperson of Telstra will be an Australian, the head office of Telstra will be in Australia, the majority of the directors will be Australian and, in terms of the service provisions, there will be penalty clauses in the legislation, which we have called a customer service guarantee, to make sure that some of the services which are offered by Telstra are delivered. The service provision of Telstra will be reinforced by this legislation.

These hares that have been running are without any substance. The fact is that there is no doubt that this bill will enhance the running of Telstra and will provide a significant benefit to the Australian environment and our economy by retiring debt.

I will look for a second at the position of the Democrats. They claim that they have a mandate to `keep the bastards honest'—I think that is the expression. They are forgetting a couple of things. The first is that what they are doing is keeping the bastards—if the bastards are the government—dishonest because we were elected on a very firm mandate with Telstra as a key pivotal plank in our election platform.

The overwhelming majority that we obtained in the House of Representatives indicates that the Australian public wants not only the privatisation of a third of Telstra but also the associated benefits that come with it. The opposition claims that it has some sort of mandate to stop us doing this. Separate from the fact that this was a part of our plank, add to that the fact that only something like 10 per cent of the population voted for the Democrats—a very small minority compared with the overwhelming majority who voted for the coalition.

Let us look at the numbers for the last election. This is a slightly different aspect to that raised previously. In the Senate in March, 40 senators were up for election. Of the 40, 20—that is, 50 per cent—were coalition senators.
