SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —It is for good reason that Labor will vote against the sale of Telstra. It is for good reason that Labor supports the findings of the majority report of the Telstra inquiry. The findings included that Telstra should remain in full public ownership so that it may continue its nation building role not only in the delivery of services but also in the stimulus its presence as an employer gives to regional economic development. Secondly, public interest in creating and retaining employment in Australia, especially in regional areas, should be given due weight in Telstra's organisational decisions. The committee particularly opposes decisions contained in Project Mercury documents which would see Telstra operations relocated offshore in the name of efficiency. Thirdly, Telstra's employment levels should be determined on the basis of operational needs rather than head count targets. Fourthly, Telstra operations should be resourced to a level that allows for ongoing improvements in customer service.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor believes that Telstra must stay totally in public hands. It is the only way to ensure that what has already contributed to building the nation continues to build the nation. Telstra is a highly successful company as its $2.3 billion in profits this year indicate. At the same time, it offers a unique service. Despite Australia's geography and demography it provides an affordable communications service on a universal basis.

As a government enterprise, it has balanced its commercial objectives against other social goals. Public ownership is the only way that these social goals can be guaranteed. As overseas experience shows, public ownership is the only way that important community service obligations can be maintained. The government often cites the sale of British Telecom as an example of a successful privatisation of a telecommunications company, but many local British consumers would have a very different viewpoint. A 1993 report by the UK National Consumer Council found:
Charges in services to domestic users have risen over the years relative to charges for services used mainly by business customers.

Thus, under a privatised service, cheap rate local calls, which are used mainly by domestic consumers, rose 27 per cent while peak rate local, national and long distance calls, which are mainly used by businesses, reduced substantially. As well, the cost of calls made from public payphones increased dramatically after British Telecom was sold.

Another often quoted example of private sector efficiency is Bell Atlantic. This company serves a market of 19 million lines on the east coast of America. It is a large telecommunications company with revenue of some $18 billion. In search of greater profit for the period 1992 to 1994, they cut 1,600 employees from their payroll. Access lines per employee rose from 288 in 1992 to 310 in 1994.

As a result of these changes, service quality dropped significantly, with their repeat trouble report rate rising sharply. In fact, it quadrupled over the period of job reductions. The repeat trouble report rate is the main measure of customer satisfaction. It records the number of times a customer has to follow up an initial fault before it is fixed. Labor believes that public ownership of Telstra is about more than just making money; it is about ensuring equity and affordability in the provision of key services. At the centre of that access and affordability has been Telstra's role in ensuring that all Australians, wherever they reside or carry on business, will continue to have reasonable access on an equitable basis to both standard telephone services and an array of benefits that new technology delivers.

BREAK.PARA: Few in the community believe that this social and policy goal will survive privatisation. The recently reconstituted board has been carefully chosen to facilitate a profit driven culture within Telstra in preparation for privatisation. In the government's view of a privatised Telstra, the third of Telstra's board legally responsible to the private shareholders will clearly have maximum profits as their priorities—not cross‐subsidisation or expanded services to the needy. Cross-subsidisation is crucial for this country because of our widely dispersed population, and it ensures that rural Australians have cheap access to the public network at what, historically, have been uniform prices.

The cost of this service is substantial. As indicated in Telstra's 1994-95 total losses from loss making exchanges, it was a massive $238.5 million. But this substantial figure greatly understates the full extent of cross-subsidies involved in current service delivery. For example, Telstra is required by law to provide service connection for all customers, irrespective of geographic location. For this service alone, Telstra sustains losses of some $170 million a year.

I am sure this fact is not lost on the many National Party supporters who are currently concerned about the prospects of a withdrawal of Telstra from regional Australia. Earlier this week, several prominent rural women met with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and expressed concerns about the effects of the sale on rural Australia. Mrs Jean Tom, a Victorian farmer, was reported on page 6 of the Australian of 16 October 1996 as saying that there were concerns that the efficiency of telecommunication links in rural areas would not be kept up to scratch, leading to higher costs

PARA.BREAK: The Telstra inquiry report reinforced this view. It found that privatisation efficiencies resulted in the centralisation of services in Sydney and Melbourne, reduced cross‐subsidies worth some $9.2 million to Telstra's Tasmanian operations, the relocation of operator assistance services to overseas locations, and the reduction in customer service centres, which are a key source of employment in regional centres. The govern ment has made much of its continued universal service obligation guarantees, but already we have had ample evidence of how this government delivers on its guarantees.

BREAK.PARA: These guarantees and promises have a very limited lifespan—ask the staff at the ABC. Section 8CM in the proposed new part 2C of the act ties the universal obligation to what should be fulfilled as efficiently and economically as practicable. This is hardly a solid assurance when we put it in the context of private rather than public ownership. An obligation on the investment considerations of a private company becomes whatever is practicable and economically acceptable to the private shareholders.

What will this obligation mean for remote communities where private providers may consider the cost of providing the service to be too excessive? Clearly, in the long term, private carriers will be either unwilling or unable to sustain cross-subsidisation. Current community service obligations will be abandoned by the provider in a competitive, deregulated environment and will only be paid at the discretion of the government of the day. They become a budget item and Mr Costello, or his successor, will decide what breadth and quality of service the government is willing to pay for from year to year.

That should provide some interesting tests of the beliefs of the National Farmers Federation in the merits of privatisation. The difficulties of expanding the definition of the universal service obligation will be increased by privatising Telstra. In the past, remote, rural and many Aboriginal communities have suffered substantial disadvantage associated with isolation. The previous Labor government recognised this inequity and foreshadowed a possible expansion of the universal service obligation from a standard telephone service to a standard telecommunications service capable of supporting fax, data and telephony.

The new government is also committed to examining the possibilities of upgrading the definition. Such an upgrade would substantially improve the quality of life for many in rural and remote communities by accessing new services, but would reduce substantially the profitability of the organisation and reduce share prices. It is not surprising that the government is hedging its bets on this one. It has gone for a minimalist definition of the standard of service in its new legislation, confining it to voice telephony. But it has left the door open for an extension of the USO by adding in other prescribed services that might have to be delivered. Right now, as the draft stands, all Telstra has to commit to is the status quo—hardly a great leap forward into the information age.

Of particular odium is the government's linking of the sale of Telstra to their environmental promises. This ploy, designed to win over the green movement, has failed. It has failed not only because it is in principle wrong to link two distinctly different agendas but, more importantly, because most environmentalists realise that a publicly owned Telstra with ongoing profits—expected to rise by 18 per cent a year—will contribute far more to the environment in the long term than a quick fire sale today.

Questions need to be asked about the coalition's ongoing commitment to environmental programs. Will they use the profits from their planned sale of the other two‐thirds of Telstra to fund future environmental programs? What happens when the Telstra piggy bank is sold? Will they then turn to other assets, such as Australia Post?

We should not trade off the further enhancement of a national infrastructure and the telecommunications sector for the price of programs to conserve our national heritage. Good government is about balancing and reconciling equal priorities. We the Australian people have the right to hold onto our precious national assets. We deserve a sustainable, natural environment, a world‐class and affordable telecommunications service and a parliament that protects all Australians equally.

Labor believes that the government's case for privatisation of Telstra is based on rhetorical and ideological arguments rather than on empirical evidence. Telstra is already a highly successful company, as its record $2.3 billion profit this year indicates. Its financial performance is equal to that of its international peers. At the same time, it provides a unique service. Despite the difficulties presented by Australia's geography and demography, Australian society has one of the highest levels of telephone access in the world.

Telstra has played an important role in nation building through the provision of affordable communications services on a universal basis. It has pioneered research and development of international importance and has been a leader in the introduction of technologies such as ISDN and fibre optics. It has played a critical role in the growth of the Australian electronics industry. At the same time, as one of the country's largest employers, it has provided job opportunities throughout Australia.

Telstra has performed this role because, as a government enterprise, it has been required to balance commercial objectives against other social goals. Labor believes that any privatisation of Telstra will weaken the government's ability to use Telstra as a vehicle for both nation building and the pursuit of a democratic communications policy.

What will be the impacts? At risk in any privatisation of Telstra are: access to advanced communications services; service availability, quality and price; public sector finances; Australian ownership; employment; and local manufacturing. Labor considers that these risks, especially that of majority foreign ownership, are heightened by the fact that the government clearly intends to sell all of Telstra over time, about which the minister let the cat out of the bag the other week.

Telstra is currently 100 per cent Australian owned and all Australians share in the benefits of that ownership. Its profits remain in Australia and are either redistributed by government or reinvested, chiefly in the national network. Privatisation would concentrate these profits in the hands of a few, to the detriment of the many. It would also allow a substantial portion of Telstra's profits to be sent out of Australia altogether.

Privatisation would rob the public sector of a major revenue stream. I would note that on current performance Telstra's profits over the next three years will equal the $8 billion the government expects to gain from the one‐third sale of the company. Depending on the government's dividend policy, Telstra could pay $8 billion in dividends over the next six to seven years. This year's dividend alone would provide the $1 billion earmarked for the National Heritage Fund. Labor consider that the sale of such a high performing asset makes no economic sense, especially as Telstra finances its own capital expansion, has no debt to the Commonwealth and has a negligible amount of Commonwealth guaranteed debt.

Labor views with concern Telstra's plans to initiate large‐scale job reductions in preparation for privatisation. Twenty‐three thousand Australian workers are to be displaced, either through direct reductions or contracting out. Many of these job losses will be in regional and rural areas. Details of project Mercury, revealed in the Senate report, show that these reductions are being driven by the desire to meet certain head count targets rather than through actual changes in Telstra's operational needs. Labor condemns these attempts to sacrifice Australian jobs in order to make Telstra more attractive to private investors.

Labor notes with particular concern Telstra's plans to cut staffing levels at the Telstra Research Laboratories, TRL, by 44 per cent over the next four years. Such cuts represent a serious threat to the future viability of TRL, which is currently the leading telecommunications research centre in Australia and the largest in the Southern Hemisphere. They pose a question as to the extent of Telstra's ongoing commitment to research and development and thus to Australia's ability to maintain a critical mass of research expertise in this central industry.

Labor also regards Telstra's proposal to close its manufacturing operations at East Bentleigh as a further blow to employment in Victoria. Labor supports the campaign of the CEPU to prevent this closure.

What will be the impact on services? Labor considers that the privatisation of Telstra will confer no certain benefits on Australian consumers and will expose them to many uncertainties. The large‐scale labour shedding which Telstra is proposing must put severe strains on the company's capacity to maintain service standards.

Privatisation will also increase the pressure on the range of cross‐subsidies which underpin the current universal service regime. Labor believes that it is already Telstra's view that any non‐commercial obligations on Telstra should be funded from the federal budget. Privatisation will strengthen the push for such measures, leaving rural and regional consumers at the mercy of the budget cycle.

Why are we having this debate? Why is the government so hell‐bent on selling off one of Australia's greatest companies? Is there an economic argument? Many attempts have been made by the government and its stooges to quote international studies, such as the 1992 World Bank report: Privatisation—lessons of experience. This report refers to some 6,800 privatisations; 4,500 of these were in the former German Democratic Republic; 6,100 were in Eastern Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean.

As examples of the benefits accruing from privatisation, the study pointed to a previously near moribund textile company in Niger, a finance company in Swaziland and an agro‐industrial enterprise in Mozambique. Just 170 of the privatisations examined by this report occurred in OECD countries. Despite this, the Department of Communications and the Arts submission described the World Bank report as `perhaps the most compelling overall review of the effects of privatisation and relationship with liberalisation'.

Other supporters of the sale were reduced to quoting from studies such as the Polish cement and lime sector, Odessa meat, the Swarzedz Furniture Company in Poland, the Trinidad and Tobago Methanol Company, textiles in Tunisia—

—That is very unfair, Senator Calvert—and privatisation in Haiti. No, this was not taken from a Monty Python script, as some senators might think, but represents the best that the ideologues could cobble together to support them.

BREAK.PARA: Can Telstra be compared with Odessa meat, textile companies in Tunisia, or Russian or East German companies? How has Telstra been performing? Much of the popular case for the privatisation of Telstra rests on suggestions that Telstra is underperforming in public ownership. In particular it is claimed that its cost structures and its staffing levels are below world best practice. Yet, on 13 September, Telstra announced a profit after tax, abnormals and minority interests of $2.305 billion for the financial year ended on 30 June 1996.

On the day these massive profits were announced, business editor Alan Kohler said on the 7.30 Report that Telstra's unit costs per line are now below the average of the world's telecommunication companies for the first time. Kohler commentated:
. . . they're 8 per cent below the average of the world and they're planning now to stay there.
So there is no reputable, comparable economic studies to support the government's case. So I ask again: why?

It does not take long when you look through the donors to the coalition in the last election to see who will be the beneficiaries. It will not be ordinary Australians, that is for sure. It will be the spivs and the paper shufflers who make up the Liberal Party branches and attend their $1,000 a head lunches and diners. This is just like the gun advertising tender—a fix for their mates. We are going to be hearing more about both of these issues over the next few weeks in the chambers and in the estimates hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate today on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill, Senator Woods mentioned the idea of keeping people honest. It is one of those views I have never subscribed to because I believe that, if it were the case that people were not honest, then the best we can do in a political sense is keep them accountable. It is my view that the sale of Telstra takes us one further step away from keeping government accountable for the provision of services such as the important services we are talking about today.

SPEECH.PARA: The name of the bill is very well chosen in my belief. The primary issue here is precisely that the public ownership is being irrevocably diluted. The secondary issue is that consolidation of global oligopoly is being increased. I am going to provide briefly here some of the background that usually does not get delivered in these kinds of debates. I will continue to do it to give a picture of what is happening in reality.

Globally, we do not have increased competition; we have increased consolidation of wealth, ownership and economic power. This has happened especially since the 1980s, when the major deregulation of the financial markets occurred. That was in preparation for the Uruguay Round of GATT in many cases.

Prior to that time, transnationals were still partially bound to work within national economies. Companies like Alcoa—the aluminium company of America—General Motors and so on had to set up national subsidiaries such as Alcoa Australia, GM Holden and so on. Today they do not.

However, we have seen the rise of international competition for investment. This means that we do not have companies competing for investment; we have nations competing for investment. Competition is based on increased corporate profit. This does not serve consumers or national interests, in my opinion.

Monopoly practice is when vertical integration—ownership from resource extraction to retail sale—shifts to horizontal integration; that is, the ownership of alternative and associated industries. There is a new term, however—coopetition. This was coined, I believe, by the Financial Review. Coopetition is a cartel by any other name.
I refer to a Financial Review article from Monday, 30 September 1996 entitled `Competition is dead. Long live co-petition!' written by Colleen Ryan from Washington. It states:
Bill Gates didn't start it, but he is one of its most successful exponents.
The alliance between Bill Gates's software manufacturer, Microsoft, and Andy Groves's chip maker, Intel, is a classic example of the concept.
The justifications for these new alliances range from—
and this has been starting for a long time, I must say—
"People can't do it on their own anymore" to "It's just too tough out there in the competitive world". Or "It's a natural consequence of the new technology, particularly in telecommunications—
does that ring a bell with anybody?—
which requires such huge levels of investment". Or "It is the outcome of the extreme levels of specialisation required these days".
The article also states:
The information superhighway has spawned a number of alliances—the argument being that no single company can afford to build and operate something so complex.
So we have a globalisation trend. It is primarily job cutting globally. It eliminates national regional services. It eliminates competition. It is, in fact, inefficient.

The result is a minimalist structure which plays to the lowest denominator mass market or to the heaviest user. That could be, as it seems to be very quickly turning out in Australia, business users as opposed to private users or regional and rural users. It presents the highest return option globally. Whatever the act is that presents the highest return or the greatest assurances of high returns is what the corporation does.

Effectively, this is part of the concentration of wealth. Many large global corporations have bigger annual budgets than the budgets of many nations. It is fundamental control of resources through market dominance. This allows companies to determine the cost and the availability of goods and services including information and culture, which have become commodified. All of these things become commodities that you can just buy and sell, like everything else. Football teams as well; you can buy and sell entire sports through this level of commoditisation. Of course, along with that you have your communications networks. That is what allows you to do this buying and selling of sports. This is part of what we are seeing.

While theoretically it is possible to be competitive, effective systems of interpersonal communication are natural monopolies. Internationally, in the presence of global consolidation of broadcast communication of news and entertainment, the establishment of alternative information and cultural outlets of production is extremely difficult and the barriers to market entry are immense. What is necessary for network infrastructure in telecommunications are cables, satellites, Internet linkages, electronic computer communications technology, software technology and financial networking services. In service provision, there are phone and fax services, computer services and broadband services. In the content provision, there are news services, entertainment services, information services; and there are personal services such as e-mail, et cetera, financial services and marketing. It is huge.

Telecommunications, as you can see, is a heavily linked area. What we see is a vast increase in consolidation in this area. The big players are those like Microsoft, Murdoch and CNN. At this point I refer you to another article, which came from a feature in the Sydney Morning Herald, page 33. It is an article by Malcolm Maiden, entitled `Welcome to his new world'. After reading this article, it is hard to escape from the conclusion that the main role of, say, the Murdoch group's newspapers now is to bankroll Murdoch's main game—and that is the construction of a global electronic network centred on television but embracing on-line interactive programming and services.

Globalisation means that, effectively, you must deal with transnational corporations. If you do not use CNN, where do you get your news? So you are actually cutting out competition rather than increasing it. We are looking at the formation of one big corporation. Film, TV production, news production, distribution, marketing, broadcasting services, cable services, news, reviews, phones, fax, computer network services, computer network and communications, technology and software.

Along with those articles on Murdoch was an article indicating that, for something like $3 billion, Murdoch now has become the largest owner of TV stations in the United States. So, whether Australia or the United States, you see these mega‐corporations that are gaining all the links to the chain. The result is the effective ownership of global news by CNN, and we get an automatic American bias to our media, to the news that we receive—to that upon which we are able to make our decisions. This gives effective control of entertainment and public information: for example, Fox Warner—once again, an American bias, globalisation of culture and control of information, attitude and opinion.

The ownership of telecommunication extends the trend to telephones, cable TVs and computer networks. You can note that we now have e-mail and fax set to displace postal services, other than parcel post delivery. In fact, we will have the privatisation of parcel post, but other areas of mail are now part of those international global networks that can be controlled. Telephone and videophone services are already becoming common through computers connected with broadband cables to the net. Dual digital TV monitors are becoming more common, as are CD sound links. We have increased congruence of information and entertainment, or `infotainment'. It is likely that in the future most postal communications will be by e-mail and fax.

We already see newspapers, like the New York Times and the Financial Review, and magazines moving on line. Government publications are moving on line, including Hansard. Ultimately, much of the print media may move to electronic form. The terms of access and the costs of access to network services will be significant. Ultimate control of personal subscription and public communications has huge implications.

The media implications are also important. The collapse of national and regional culture is a possibility, as are the collapse of national identity and the collapse of diversity of viewpoints globally funnelled through a few very large corporations for main line profit. Then there is the domination of profit motive.

This all might seem far-fetched. But if you think about the fact that we are moving here in Australia as well to privatise the ABC, where do we get the alternative viewpoint to this kind of level of control? For people who do not see what this has to do with the privatisation of Telstra, I am very worried indeed. We might see the end of media as a vocation; perhaps the domination of a sound byte mentality and the domination of ratings. We will see a lot of changes. We are seeing, as I say, cutbacks to the ABC proposed—the elimination of the remaining avenue for some quality thought and differing opinions.

This all serves the interests of profit but not the interests of the public. It can only result in further erosion of employment and Australian culture—and it is tied into telecommunications; it is a global domination of all forms of communication.

To get back to the bill, we have many problems with this bill itself, apart from those very real problems that we see with the current trend towards the privatisation of such an element as Telstra. The public control is immensely important, but the partial sale of Telstra eliminates any ability of government to effectively take an active role in direction of the company.

The government is seeking to reassure people by insisting on the right to special reports through its amendment of the Telstra Corporation Act, but this only allows a minister to demand special financial statements and other information not available to stockholders. The proposed amendments exclude the Commonwealth in Telstra from the requirements in the Corporations Law that would prevent that. The existing general power of the minister to direct Telstra is being removed by item 25 of schedule 1 on page 48.

There are implications of privatisation going along with an inadequate national code. That is not in the bill but, once you have changed that, the huge public interest—as I have mentioned before in talking about the report of Telstra—is there and obviously glaring us in the face. The fact that the draft codes, which have been released by the government, continue to allow exemption from state and local planning and environmental codes would indicate that these financial pressures are biting already.

The government sees any social agenda as in conflict with the private sector and believes the government has no right to reduce their profits by serving public ends. So this government is basically putting profits above public ends. Beyond that, the government has perceived the assuring of high profits to global corporations, and hamstringing public interest, as a primary means of improving our economic situation. The fact that many people seem to disagree with that seems to be irrelevant.

We have all had all sorts of debates about the standard telephone services and untimed local calls. Currently, section 73 of the Telecommunications Act requires an option for untimed local calls for a standard telephone service to be made by Telecom. There is nothing in the act about other telecommunication services or other carriers. No other carriers or service providers are obliged to provide an untimed option.

We have problems with the universal service obligation because it only applies a standard telephone service to all people in Australia on an equitable basis. The universal service carrier may not be Telstra necessarily and may be different in different areas, although I cannot imagine this at this point. The fact that there is a Standard Telephone Service Review Group set up now seems to indicate that there is a need to quell the public concern about this. It is certainly not good enough to be rushing into these issues in this way.

There is nothing in this act which defines what is `local'. There are no restrictions on the cost or availability of the untimed option. There is nothing in this bill about services other than telephones. For all that I mentioned before, it is as if we are living in the 1960s. The committee report highlights this and makes recommendations about non‐phone services. There is no guarantee that the untimed option be offered on a generally affordable basis.

The customer service guarantee has been mentioned quite a lot. I want to make it clear that Austel is only allowed to regulate if directed by the minister. Recommendation 22 said that they should be required, and recommendation 23 said that their formulation and development should include consumer representation in determining them on a full voting basis. Recommendation 24 says there should be requirements that the codes be developed within a certain time.

We will not have Austel after next year. Austel will be absorbed into the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. If people really want to see exactly what impact the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will have in operating as a so-called independent regulator of telecommunications, especially in providing any sort of guarantee of public interest, I suggest they have a look more closely into what the limitations are about public interest and about exemptions for public interest in relation to the competition policy.

There are many recommendations that came through the report, but in the brief time that I have left I want to mention a couple of other issues in relation to telecommunications in general. Telecommunications is an area of major significance. The public network has been described by Stewart Fist of the Australian as:
. . . the basic structure under which democratic communication and conduct of business is carried out. Private ownership of the market infrastructure is not equitable.

Regulation—as occurs in the United States to avoid market failure or major dichotomies in power—must, to be effective, be so sweeping that it precludes competition. Private ownership, in most places where social implications are considered, usually becomes a publicly directed national or regional monopoly. We have not seen any indications here that there is a real desire to make sure that regulations fulfil these roles.

Telecommunications is changing rapidly and massively in terms of its significance and use. It is becoming the de facto channel for financial exchange and services; information and education services; written communication; and, increasingly, audio and video communication, including entertainment and news services. How dangerous is that for us to jump in like this without thinking through the implications ahead of time?

PARA.BREAK: Who are the likely bidders for Telstra? Apart from the obvious interest of other international telecommunications companies, including foreign government owned provid ers, likely bidders will be computer companies such as IBM, computer network globals such as Microsoft and Netscape, and media and entertainment firms such as Fox‐Warner, CNN or Time‐Life. There are issues here about what the system will be and who will determine the rights of competitors and have access and on what terms. These are issues of convergence, and these are issues we have not properly dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the ridiculous connection between the Telstra sale and the environment, the proposal is to use $1 billion to create an environment fund. Telstra has also performed well in my home state of Tasmania. Tasmania's isolation obviously has an effect on our capacity to communicate. Having the phone on should be a right and not a privilege. If it were not for Telstra's public ownership and cross‐subsidisation regime, Tasmanians would be paying thousands simply to have the phone on. If it is privatised, who will be the losers? Regional and rural Australians, the sick, the poor and the elderly.

Under this government, we have seen a string of body blows to Tasmania—cuts to job creation programs, cuts to Commonwealth funds, cuts to legal aid, cuts to our university and on and on. Tasmania's economy, under a Liberal state government and under a Liberal federal government, is in an absolute shambles. This sale will compound the litany of betrayal of the people of Tasmania.

It is no accident that Tasmanians stuck with Labor in March this year. They knew what to expect because of the actions of a state Liberal government. They do not trust the government; they do not like the government; and they did not vote for the government.

Let me describe the appalling state of Tasmania's economy. The state Liberal government is slashing services right across the board. Nearly 1,000 state public sector workers are out of a job—and that is before you add on the federal government cuts. Let us turn to the federal government. Over the next three years your government will impose cuts to Tasmania in the vicinity of $160 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you come to Western Australia—we are going well.

—Let me tell you, Senator Crane, that what happened in March this year was that Tasmania actually got the best result for Labor in Australia and we almost got three senators. There was very little change in the Senate vote. Do you know why that is? Because we ran a campaign in Tasmania on what would happen to Tasmanians in relation to the sale of Telstra. SPEECH.PARA: Medicare offices are closing. We are losing the Launceston taxation office and federal public sector jobs are being slashed. All of these things mean absolute disaster for my home state. The recent Access Economics report has predicted that the Tasmanian economy will grow by only 0.7 of half a per cent over the next year. Our unemployment rate remains the nation's highest—it is currently at 10.7 per cent, seasonally adjusted—and youth unemployment is a staggering 24.9 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: This government is now proposing that Telstra be partially privatised. Let me enlighten the Senate as to how a partial sale will further depress the Tasmanian economy. Telstra currently employs a total of 1,460 people in Tasmania. On 13 September this year, Telstra confirmed that it plans to shed 22,000 jobs nationally. If this cut is implemented across the board, it will mean the loss of some 500 jobs in Tasmania. In addition, many of the remaining positions will be transferred to Melbourne, stripping Tasmania of employment in high value added areas of Telstra. The real number of job losses in Tasmania could end up being closer to 700.

These jobs have been on the line only since the change of government. As Telstra prepares itself for a partial privatisation, Telstra chiefs have said that the jobs need to be cut to make Telstra more competitive. Surely a company recording a profit of $2.3 billion is already competitive. Telstra's wage bill in Tasmania is currently in the order of $51 million. If half the jobs go, half the wages go—even those on the other side can understand that. The removal of this amount of cash from the Tasmanian economy is something we simply cannot afford.

Tony Rundle, the most pathetic Premier our state has ever seen, cannot even see through the blackmail inherent in the promise that Tasmania will receive a lion's share of the Natural Heritage Trust. His eyes are dazzled by the idea of a few lousy dollars.

Given what has happened to Tasmania over the last six to eight months, I guess Mr Rundle will clutch at any kind of straw in relation to job creation. He sold his state down the drain, pure and simple. And it is not just economics: there are community service obligations that need to be looked at.

The universal service obligations set out in this bill are not good enough. They are not good enough for Australia, nor for Tasmania. There is no provision for the standard telephone service to include technological advancements such as broadband services and so on. This is despite spurious assurances from Senator Alston that:
The extent to which people in rural and remote areas have access to services is obviously critical if they are not to be left behind in keeping up with the latest technologies.

The likelihood of the universal service obligation being broadened to include these technologies is remote as it would reduce the profitability of Telstra. If you are about making a buck—and the company is about making a buck, and that is the sole motivation—then that is logical. It makes sense. This would lower the price of stock that this government would get from the fire sale of Telstra. Senator Alston said in this place:
Optus has indicated an interest that will extend to Tasmania.
He went on to say:
I have no doubt that if Tasmanians are interested in the service, Telstra will be looking at it as well.

`Looking at it' is about as far as it will get, let me assure you. There is no guarantee of access. Both Telstra and Optus have confirmed that they have no intention of rolling out broadband cable in Tasmania. That has been confirmed; they have no intention whatsoever. Telstra will not do it because Optus is not going to do it—pure and simple.

Tasmania cannot be guaranteed access to pay TV. We will end up with Internet access that is simply not up to scratch. Tasmania faces a future with a second‐rate communications system, a system which will disadvantage consumers and disadvantage the business community. Businesses in Tasmania are trying to compete for a market share through the Internet, and they will be way behind the eight ball. If you want to run a business in Tasmania and have access to those kinds of services, you will have to run the business out of Melbourne in order to get access to state of the art technology. That is ridiculous and absurd.

This will mean a decrease in business investment and a further slowing of what could be kindly described as an already limping economy. Tasmania will become a technological backwater as a result of this initiative, and the people of Tasmania know it. If a partial sale goes through, there is no way that Tasmania will be assured of access to the latest technology. The only way that Tasmania can be guaranteed this access is if the minister has the power to direct Telstra to ensure that that access is there.

However, the loss of ministerial direction is just one of the many safeguards that will go under this bill. The cross‐subsidisation rates, which currently are provided by Telstra, are absolutely critical for regional Tasmania. Under the existing universal service obligations, the annual access cost per line is highly subsidised in my state. Let me give an indication of the extent of these subsidies. In Burnie, for example, it costs $850 per year to have a phone connected, and Flinders Island is subsidised to the extent of a staggering $4,930 per year. Even Launceston—which is actually in Bass, one of the few seats held by the Liberal Party in Tasmania—is subsidised to the extent of $730 per phone line per year. The loss of cross‐subsidisation will clearly be an absolute disaster.

Tasmania is the only state which has every one of its federal electorates receiving a cross‐subsidy for the provision of telecommunications services. Tasmania is subsidised to the tune of approximately $9 million per year. These universal service obligations are not guaranteed under this bill and, despite what the government says, they will go. The offending clause in the new bill states that:
Universal service obligations . . . should be fulfilled as efficiently and economically as possible.

If private owners of Telstra decide that the universal service obligation is not efficient or economical, they will say they do not want to fund it—that is what will happen—and we will have lost the ability to make them.

This clause is the carrot for foreign investors. It has quite deliberately been put in there. This is the loophole that will enable the new owners to water down the universal service obligations. This clause changes the universality of our telecommunications system. This government wants a system that links telecommunications access to the ability to pay—as with everything else this government has done. If you have got the money, you will be all right; you can get the phone on.

PARA.BREAK: Once privatised even partially, Telstra will have to comply with the Corporations Law. This law clearly states that majority share holders—that is, the government—cannot make decisions that financially disadvantage minority shareholders. That is another loophole for the removal of the universal service obligations. Tasmania is obviously in need of protection, and the status quo is the only way to guarantee that we receive it. A partial sale of Telstra could end up being the straw that breaks the camel's back for Tasmania's economy.

BREAK.PARA: This government has admitted that a privatised Telstra, under market forces, may reduce the quality of services. How do we know that? Because why else would they talk about introducing a customer service guarantee if they are not concerned about a diminution in the standard of service? That guarantee would establish minimum levels of services in areas like the time taken for connections and time taken for rectifying faults and service difficulties—not good enough.

The Senate committee looking at the bill noted that some submissions, including those of the Telecommunications Ombudsman, argue that a guarantee is not sufficient; it does not go far enough. This guarantee has no accessible enforcement mechanism. Basically, if you cannot afford to pursue the matter, tough luck.

What protection is there for Tasmanians who live in rural areas? What if their phone connection took longer than the time specified under the service guarantee? They would have to go through a process that involves a whole lot of red tape. That will take time and cost money. Effectively, their protection will be lost. That is the reality. The so‐called guarantee would be worthless.

I ask Liberal senators representing my home state to think carefully about their social and moral obligations. In doing so, I remind them of the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to the Tasmanian state Liberal conference:
We will look after and respond to the special needs and interests of Tasmania.
And:
In the years ahead we will maintain that special understanding of the particular problems and challenges to Tasmania.
What a joke! Tasmanians did not believe him then and they do not believe him now.

I say to Tasmanian Liberal senators: why don't you stand up and represent and fight for the people who actually elected you to this place? Why don't you do what the Prime Minister suggests and look after the interests of Tasmania? You have no credibility and you are letting your state down.

How do they think they got here? Tasmanians voted for Tasmanian Liberal senators in good faith, and I challenge them to do the right thing by their state. The Tasmanian Liberal senators in this place should hang their heads in shame at what they have done to Tasmania and at what this government has done to Tasmania with their complicity, their compliance, in absolute silence.

We did not hear a thing out of them when these budget cuts were being brought down in relation to Tasmania—not a peep. Senator Abetz flirted with the idea of crossing the floor but was pulled into line by the Liberal Party machine—which is ironic given his background—and that is the last we heard. This is their chance to do something positive for Tasmania and vote against the partial sale of Telstra for the state that they represent and for the people who elected them.

The partial sale of Telstra is bad news for Tasmania. The partial sale of Telstra is bad news for Australia. The bottom line is that the partial sale of Telstra is bad news—bad news for the poor, bad news for the sick, bad news for the elderly and bad news for country people.

If this bill were to go through, I can tell you, it will be bad news for the government. People will not like it. Labor has three seats in Tasmania out of five. Come the next election, we will have five out of five.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say, after listening to that contribution, is that it is in stark contrast to what I hear from the Tasmanian representatives in this federal parliament. All I can say to Senator Mackay is: if it's so bad in Tasmania, come west. It is a great state and there is a lot going on there. We are very proud of our state.

BREAK.PARA: I want to deal with the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996. The reason we are hearing so much knocking from the other side about this bill and the creation of the natural heritage fund—which was our policy position leading into the election and still is—is that we put this policy together before they did. That is their single biggest problem with this proposed legislation.

They are not big enough to turn around and admit that this concept not only would improve Telstra significantly—many people in Australia do not have the services they should have; I could link our operation to that, and I will in a moment or two—but also is the first serious attempt to deal in a practical way with some of the environmental concerns that most of us in this chamber have expressed from time to time. Their problem is that we beat them to it. That is why they are bleating so much.

I come from the south‐east part of Western Australia, and our property would probably have been the last of anybody's in this room to be connected to the telephone. It was not that long ago. We have an appreciation of the value of the telephone and the development of—

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes longer for some of us.

—You would not have an appreciation of it. You have lived in the lap of luxury, subsidised by the ability of states like Western Australia to earn real income. That is where you have lived all this time.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to talk about some of the national economic benefits of the measure before us. Communications has emerged in recent years as one of the main contributors to economic growth. The growth within the communications industry has been an astounding 18 per cent, or up to five times the growth rate of GDP. Trying to measure the precise economic value of improving an input such as communications services is difficult because it permeates all aspects of our society and because, year by year, it is becoming more important to the way in which we conduct our daily lives.

However, with or without detailed numerical analysis, we need to have a clear view of the importance of improvements in communications services. I intend today to move from the macro to the micro level, to demonstrate the real value of truly efficient delivery of services to the broader economy, to the communications industry and to each of us as individuals.

Next, I will deal with the broad economic benefits. Australia has been the lucky country in many respects. However, our geographic position in the world and our demographic spread have been major obstacles to accessing markets in commerce and trade. Our relative geographic isolation from major markets has constrained our economic potential. Distance from growth markets, even the north‐east Asian markets, has limited our ability to trade and to establish a sustained presence in a number of key trade areas.

The problem has been compounded by an economies of scale problem whereby Australian firms have made one‐off deals in particular regions, but are not seen as serious contenders next to large American or European corporations because we cannot finance a sustained presence in these countries. With efficient communications services, our businesses have the opportunity to overcome this barrier of distance to markets and be in a position to compete on an equal basis with other countries.

Large and small firms will be able to keep in touch with potential buyers electronically without the requirement for expensive representation on the ground. There is a considerable potential for Australian firms to become active in areas where we have considerable expertise, such as the remote sensing, agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining industries. There are also opportunities in service sectors such as telemedicine and education.

To become an export focused economy—and we must really address our balance of payment problems—we need to get overseas markets and require efficient world‐class telecommunications links both domestically and overseas. Efficiency in the provision of communications services in Australia will act as a catalyst in opening opportunities for a range of Australian businesses overseas. We must take the steps that are necessary to gain this efficiency; otherwise the traditional problems of access to overseas markets will continue.

The barrier of distance also applies to large and small firms operating within Australia. Through efficient, affordable communications services, we have perhaps more to gain than any other country in the world by allowing producers and consumers to interact across continents. This is no small point and we should reflect on this for a moment.

The cost and availability of communications services may be the difference between securing a new contract or placing a new order. In short, it could be the difference between viability and bankruptcy.

In debating this bill, we need to think about these sorts of issues. The only way we are going to get sustainable jobs and improved standards is through profitable businesses. Profitable businesses need efficient communications services.

I mentioned earlier the difficulty in measuring the economic value of improving communications services. Despite this there has been some analysis and, as commonsense would dictate, gains at the micro level are quickly translated into massive gains at the macro‐economic level.

Telstra's submission to the recent Senate inquiry provided a detailed exposition of benefits in terms of GDP growth, consumer surplus, more efficient use of the community's resources, improved international competitiveness and reducing the relative cost disadvantages experienced by business and residents in rural and remote regions of Australia. The submission stated:

According to Industry Commission analysis, adoption of Hilmer‐type competition reforms in the telecommunications sector was estimated to achieve significant improvements in GDP of the order of $2.7 billion. Follow‐up analysis by the Centre for Regional Economic Analysis showed that all industries and every state of Australia would benefit from these reforms. This is because virtually every business in Australia is connected to a telephone network and therefore uses a component of communications as an input in the production process.

It is also important from an international competitiveness viewpoint that Australia has an efficient and minimum cost telecommunications infrastructure. Improving productivity within Telstra and the industry assists exporters (and potential exporters) to compete in international markets and domestic‐focused firms to compete with imports. Higher exports and import substitution both operate to increase measured domestic GDP. Furthermore, this could lessen (although difficult to quantify) the current account deficit. Historically a major cyclical constraint to economic growth in Australia.

The inquiry also heard that the Department of Communications and the Arts had commissioned some modelling of the potential economic gains arising from improving Telstra's labour and capital efficiency.

This built on work done previously by EPAC and the Industry Commission and suggests that there are some significant potential gains to the wider Australian economy simply through improving Telstra's technical efficiency—that is, without taking account of likely changes to service offerings. This work was summarised as follows: for labour, efficiency gains of 15 per cent, 30 per cent and 45 per cent were modelled for the communications sector as a whole. These correspond to improving Telstra's ratio of access lines per employee to about 160, 190 and 220 respectively, adjusted for Telstra's market share.

For capital, efficiency gains of zero, 10 per cent and 20 per cent were modelled. Notably, the middle case scenario—a 30 per cent gain in labour efficiency and a 10 per cent gain in capital efficiency spread over four years—indicated the following. Private consumption, which is an indicator of living standards, would increase by $1.7 billion or a permanent 0.6 per cent gain. There would be an 11 per cent fall in the long run price of communications services. An associated gain in the economy wide GDP peaking at 0.5 per cent—that is, $2.4 billion—by the year 2002‐3 would moderate to 0.35 per cent—or $1.7 billion—in the long run and on a continuing basis.

A decline in employment in the communications sector of 17.5 per cent would be offset by increases in other sectors in the long run. The economy wide gain would be $3 per employee per week in 1995‐96 prices. Allowing for the limits of modelling of this type, there are clearly significant benefits to the economy, businesses and consumers from increased efficiency in Telstra and the communications sectors generally.

Clearly, there are very real benefits for the economy as a whole from improving Telstra's efficiency because of Telstra's importance in the telecommunications sector and the significance of telecommunications to other sectors. The benefits of efficiency gains in Telstra will permeate virtually every area of economic and community activity.

The telecommunications industry is the star performer in the Australian economy. As I have mentioned, the industry is currently growing at around 18.1 per cent or five times the growth of GDP. But this performance needs to be put in context; otherwise we may be tempted to agree with the opposition's approach of sitting back and not making any preparation for the future.

Telecommunications is a growth industry world wide. This technology plus—and I emphasise the `plus'—efficiency gain is driving this rapid growth. In Australia we are receiving some of the benefits of technology improvement, but we are not getting the gain from efficiency. In short, while this result is good, it is not as good as it could be.

Telstra, as the major player in the industry, must pull its weight. By being less efficient than it could be, it is effectively constraining the potential of the rest of the sector. Achieving efficiency in Telstra is, therefore, vitally important to the entire telecommunications sector and the growth that has been achieved in recent years will be further assisted by an improved performance by Telstra.

I turn now to the benefits for the home. This debate is not just about the effect on business and cold hard numbers; it is also about the quality of people's lives. Telecommunications services are an integral part of our home life in terms of both conducting our personal daily business and keeping in touch with friends and family. All those in the chamber tonight—

TALK.START.PARA: —That only indicates how confused you are.

—I am not confused at all, I was initially to deliver this speech tomorrow night. I will correct myself. All of those in the chamber today would be aware of how they are increasingly making use of communications technology to make the duties of office more manageable and to maintain contact with family and friends. Can you imagine the difficulty you would face in not having a fax machine, an answering machine or even a mobile phone available? Very shortly we will be equally reliant on the Internet access to conduct business and communicate with family members.

BREAK.PARA: Communication services reduce the direct cost and ease the burden that we all face in conducting our daily tasks. Already we do not have to go to a bank to do our banking for an increasing number of items. We do not have to go to a shop to do our shopping. They also provide added benefits that cannot be assessed in monetary terms by improving our ability to cope with days in which time is increasingly at a premium.

Telecommunications services clearly provide economic and other benefits to the household. This is evidenced by the fact that we all want access to new communications services at affordable prices and is reflected in the incredible interest there is in the entire debate.

The conclusion is not only simple and obvious but also vitally important to Australia's future. If Australia is to compete internationally and make full use of the current telecommunications services and the raft of new services to come, we must have access to these services at affordable prices. Government alone cannot provide these services, and protective barriers to operation will not guarantee them in the long term. The only way Australians will get the communications services they need is through an efficient, internationally competitive industry.

The government wants Telstra to continue to be a key player in the Australian telecommunications market in the future. The Telstra bill is about achieving an efficient Telstra to ensure that it has a major role in Australia's telecommunications future. To deny the need for an efficient Telstra, as the opposition parties have done in their rejection of this bill, is either to condemn the company to eventual strangulation by more efficient competitors or to assume that Australia must accept a second-rate telecommunications system.

This government will not accept the opposition's second‐best solutions. Australia cannot be held captive by the antiquated ideology of the sanctity of public ownership if we are to join the vast majority of OECD countries that have embarked on privatisation and have realised the full potential of their telecommunications carriers.

This bill represents a driving force in improving Telstra's efficiency and making sure that the company flourishes. It also represents a significant step in ensuring that Australia reaps the full benefits of the communications age.

In conclusion, the principal reason for the noises we have heard coming from the other side, and for their consistent complaining about this particular legislation, is that we in government, and prior to the last election, were able to get both the heritage trust fund and the reform of Telstra up as a policy position. There is very wide endorsement out in the community in terms of the policy positions that we went to the last election with.

Furthermore, I would like to mention a few things from the point of view of my own state of Western Australia. If what is happening over there continues—the continued development of our mining industries, the continued development of the initial stages and longer of providing income for this country, export dollars for this country, the continued improvement in our agricultural efficiency and all the other various aspects that go with life over there—it is absolutely essential that we keep pace with what is happening in the rest of the world.

As I have acknowledged here before, Telstra has done a fantastic job to this point in time. Now is the time to move into the new age, a different era. It is a different situation; it is not the same as what it was 10 years or 15 years ago. We as a nation cannot continue to support a situation which would be like putting a leg rope round a cow and holding it back, nor can those of us who come from Western Australia—at least those of us on this side of the chamber.

Now is the time to open ourselves up to a different era, a modern era—an era where Australia wants to go. It is about improving our economic performance as far as our current account situation is concerned, which we have seen happening since we got into government. It is about improving the various stocks around the country as well as the boost of confidence that has occurred. I could mention a whole range of things that I will leave to another time.

In the last 10 to 12 years of my life I have come to rely on a good telecommunications system by having a telephone. There are still a few people who do not have a telephone in Australia, but not many. By having a telephone, I do appreciate the importance of having a good, modern telecommunications service. I look forward to the time when we will no longer have to go out into our paddocks and steer our tractor, but will be able to set the program up in our houses—which is happening in some parts of Europe now—and our farming will all be done through telecommunications systems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have heard from government senators their usual diatribe about why they should be able to sell a third of Telstra. But out there in the real world I do not think it is making a great deal of impact on the average person, on the battlers that the government claims they have picked up and suddenly know all about. I am still receiving letters from constituents expressing grave concerns about the impact that this partial sale of Telstra is likely to have. Even in today's edition of the Central Western Daily in Orange, which I will read out later, there is a letter to the editor again expressing their concerns and their worries about what may happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra is one of Australia's greatest assets. It is part of our social infrastructure. It provides nearly 90 per cent of Australia's telecommunications services. It makes no sense at all to sell a company that made an after tax profit of $1.7 billion in 1994-95 and $2.305 billion in 1995-96.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did the Commonwealth Bank make?

—The most important reason not to sell off Telstra, from my point of view as a person coming from a rural area, is to protect the universal service obligations. No matter what the government says, the USOs will be in danger because the coalition wants to remove the minister's power to direct Telstra. This will have an impact in many areas of Telstra's operations, but the main impact will be in the provision of universal service obligations. If the minister cannot direct the company, then the universal service obligations can be calculated in any way, shape or form that will reduce the cost to a privatised Telstra. That increases the cost to the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the USOs at the moment involve cross‐subsidies to rural areas to reduce the cost to consumers of having a line. This cross-subsidy is very large in many parts of the country. I will give some examples of the levels of cross‐subsidy in rural New South Wales electorates: Gwydir, $13.54 million; Parkes, $15.21 million; Calare, $3.29 million; New England, $4.24 million; and Riverina, $4.06 million. If these cross‐subsidies were removed and subscribers had to pay the actual cost for their telephone line, it would be out of reach of all but the wealthiest in many areas.

I will give the Senate some examples of the cross‐subsidy value per annum per individual line in rural New South Wales: in Bathurst, $880 per annum per line; in Orange, $980 per annum per line; in Narrabri, $1,500 per annum per line; in Glen Innes, $2,300 per annum per line; and in Broken Hill, $3,400 per annum per line. The government is prepared to put this assistance to people at risk.

This is the government that says it supports small business. Most small businesses have at least two lines coming into their businesses and one private line at home as a bare minimum. How can you tell me that people in a place like Broken Hill can afford to lose some of the $9,000-plus cross-subsidisation that they receive each year for those three phones? They cannot.

The electors of Broken Hill knew it as well, because the swing in Broken Hill did not happen. We maintained our vote. So the electors of Broken Hill were quite able to understand the rhetoric that the government was trying to spread at that stage when they were in opposition.

I know that the people of Broken Hill would not be prepared, or able, to pay even a part of their $3,000-plus a year for just one phone line. The people of rural Australia will be at a great disadvantage if the universal service obligations were to fall by the wayside. And, rest assured, they will if this government sells Telstra and does not retain the ministerial power to direct the new owners.

The process is already under way to reduce USOs. Currently under review is the definition of a `standard telephone service' to be provided under the universal service obligation. The minister believes that the universal service has already been achieved and that those people who do not have a telephone can access it through `a neighbour's phone, a payphone, a phone at work or even a postal service'. For some people in rural and remote areas, it is a bit difficult to find the nearest payphone. It just shows how out of touch this government is with rural conditions.

This would leave only the postal service for people on farms, which is a totally unsatisfactory situation in this day and age. A reduction in the USOs would be highly inequitable and discriminate against people in rural and remote areas. To dramatically increase the cost for them would put them at a great disadvantage and would aid what this government is doing all the time; that is, reducing services to the bush and causing a bleeding of the population from the bush to the city. The government has exacerbated this situation already. This bill will do that even more so.

Access to the information superhighway and further advances in communications technology is also a real issue for people in rural areas. It is a concern and a wish list of those people to see these things become part of the standard telephone service. If you live in the city, you can log onto modems and the Internet and you pay at the local call rate; but in the bush it is at STD rates. There is a great push in the minds of rural based people to have the same access to communications technology, and they feel that this should be included in the USOs.

I am also very concerned about the impact on jobs, particularly in rural areas, that the sale of Telstra will have. At present, Telstra employs over 200 people in Bathurst and 130 people in Orange. In Bathurst, there are 90 people in the customer service centre. Telstra is a significant employer in many country towns and cities. If the government abolishes those services and jobs in country towns it is going to place a huge drain on the services and cause a huge loss in those communities.

There is also the multiplier effect of a loss of wages and people having to move. A lot of these jobs are held by women whose spouses have employment in the community and they are not in a position to find alternative work. They do not have the ability to move to another location to find alternative work. The government has gutted work training programs, so these women will not have access to those. This is the sort of thing that this government will be doing.

The sale of Telstra would most likely see the closure of a number of centres, such as the one in Bathurst, and the consolidation of employment in capital cities. Regional Telstra centres are significant sources of employment for women. Indeed, under Project Mercury, Telstra announced the abolition of 22,000 jobs over the next three years. Where will those job cuts be? The government has said that it will maintain jobs in rural areas. You cannot discriminate against one sector of the work force of Telstra. There is a wide range of skills within the services. They have not outlined with the 22,000 job cuts what skills they are going to cut. It is clear that these jobs are being shed to make this company look more attractive to potential investors.

Telstra invests heavily in rural areas. It will spend $34.5 million in the central west of New South Wales in 1996-97 to improve the service to their customers and inject hundreds of thousands of dollars a month into the local economy. The removal of many Telstra employees from this area would be detrimental to the towns in the area and the local economy. The same goes for many other rural towns around Australia.

Where is the National Party while this is going on? That is the question that is being asked in the bush. It is letting the Liberal Party roll right over them. The National Party is doing absolutely nothing to stem the tide and to stand up for the needs and aspirations of rural people. They claim to represent the interests of rural Australia, yet this bill will be extremely harsh on the very people they claim to represent. The National Party is yet again falling into step quietly behind the Liberal Party. They are not looking after their electorates.

But what about the other inequities? It is not only those in country Australia that will be hurt. There is no clause in this bill preventing Telstra, once privatised, from charging for directory assistance. TALK.START.PARA: —The tyranny of distance has always made communications vital to the development of our nation. This was recognised a century ago by the framers of our constitution, which to this day gives the Commonwealth the power to make laws with respect to communications. The organisation we know as Telstra can trace its roots back to the Postmaster‐General's Department formed in 1901 at the time of Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: So Telstra is not an ordinary company like Optus, for example. Telstra is this country's communications network. Telstra is also the jobs of thousands of Australians who build, operate and maintain that network on our behalf. Right now the Australian people find themselves in the unique position of owning the network—unique because Telstra is the only one of the top 20 telecommunications corporations by revenue in the world to remain in public ownership.

In proposing this bill, the Howard government is asking the Australian people to sell that network. But they are also being asked to sell much more. I draw your attention to page 130 of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee's report where it says:

This is a period of great opportunities—to build a fairer, wealthier, better educated and better informed nation. Government must take the lead in implementing a national strategy for the adoption of the new information and communications technologies and services. The ability to take such a lead is far greater while Telstra remains in public ownership.
