The Labor Party believes the key to such a future lies in open and equitable access to the information age. In its final report, the Broadband Services Expert Group warned:

At a time when there are concerns about the concentration of media ownership, open access will also be vital in allowing consumers access to the diversity of views to be expressed and communicated in our society . . .
It is up to us as a community to ensure that information and communication services are used to create the kind of society we want.

Creative Nation, the previous government's cultural policy statement, emphasised the role of information and communications technologies in making cultural products accessible to all Australians. It argued:
In creating and disseminating cultural materials we are weaving a fabric that unites us as a nation, and advancing our economic wellbeing.
This view, placing the importance of culture above that of the market, contrasts starkly with the government's position as spelled out in its Australia Online policy document. It says:

Commerce, not culture will be the driver of new applications and revenue. A successful online services industry will generate the critical mass of infrastructure and revenue required to exploit the new cultural opportunities now emerging.

This notion that the market alone will drive the telecommunications sector is at the heart of the government's proposal to privatise Telstra. But what has been the experience of relying on market forces alone in other service industries? For example, have changes to the banking industry made banks more accessible to more Australians? Or have we seen thousands of jobs lost as branches are closed across Australia, particularly in regional areas, making banks less accessible?

As I said earlier, Labor believes the key to the future of this country lies in open and equitable access to the new technology. The government would say it shares this commitment, so the real issue here is how this is to be achieved.
The Broadband Services Expert Group proposed the concept of `universal reach' as a way of delivering:
. . . equality of opportunity to communicate at a reasonable cost by matching the needs of the user with the communications capacity provided, rather than giving costly uniform capacity to all users.

In other words, access to the new technology could be matched to people's needs rather determined by their capacity to pay. This approach would see the construction of community information kiosks, a modern equivalent to public parks, a sort of `electronic commons'.

This concept of the electronic commons is widely accepted as a possible compromise between the need to provide universal access and the enormous costs involved. Even the coalition recognises the need for the electronic commons but views it `principally as a concept for the delivery of government services'.

I suspect the foundations of the coalition's electronic commons are already being laid. Consider the government's plan to close more than 600 Social Security and Commonwealth Employment Service offices, replacing them with 300 one-stop‐shop service delivery agencies. To achieve their objective of delivering government services electronically, all that will then be required is to place these SDAs on line. Job seekers and welfare recipients could then claim their payments by entering their information directly into the department's computers.

This is the government's vision for travel on the information superhighway for those who cannot afford to pay the toll. Already cost is looming as a significant factor in determining who does and does not have access to the new communications technology. Last month the Australian Bureau of Statistics released a survey of household use of information technology. It found that household use of computers increased consistently with income. The highest level of use was found in households with incomes of over $57,000 per year; the lowest level of use was found in households with incomes below $13,000. Of the 4.7 million households who did not use computers, almost a third cited cost as a major barrier. The numbers in each income bracket were also significantly higher for those in capital cities as opposed to the rest of Australia. So special attention needs to be paid to the needs of those in regional areas.

In its report entitled Developing Long‐term Strategies for Science and Technology in Australia, the Australian Science and Technology Council recognised the potential of the new technology to revitalise rural and remote communities across Australia. I have seen this potential realised in my home town of Ipswich. Three and a half years ago, the Ipswich City Council found itself in need of a new library, needing to attract new industries to the region and wanting a new image for the city. The council arrived at a unique solution, deciding to make Ipswich an information‐rich community.

For an initial investment of around $1 million, the Ipswich City Council became a community‐based Internet provider, establishing the Global Info Link Service at the end of 1994. It was the first council in the country to do so. Already that public investment in infrastructure is paying for itself in not only economic but also social and recreational terms. Public Internet access machines are provided in the city's library, and users are charged a modest $4 per hour. Open to all, I understand the place is usually packed, especially during school holidays. A diverse range of Ipswich businesses—from manufacturers of fishing lures to clay pavers—has also taken advantage of the Internet access.

Now primary school children in Ipswich can communicate with electronic pen pals around the world, while businesses in Ipswich have become part of the global economy. This is the power of the new information technologies. But perhaps the most significant result has been the growth of computer‐industry small businesses like equipment retailers and web site designers, of which Ipswich certainly has more than its fair share.

What has been achieved by the Ipswich City Council is an example to Australia's other regional centres. Indeed, it is an example which could easily apply to the country as a whole. It is the combination of private and public money which has allowed the Ipswich community to benefit so early from the new technologies. For no matter what the government has been telling the people of regional Australia about the benefits for them in selling Telstra, the fact remains that no business was going to come and invest in infrastructure in Ipswich on its own.

Those living in other parts of regional Australia know that the sale of Telstra holds little for them other than a further decline in their local economies and standard of living. Their concerns about job loss came through very clearly in the large number of submissions received by the Senate inquiry, particularly from North Queensland. Those concerned about the effect of this proposal on jobs have already been vindicated. Last month Telstra announced its intention to shed 22,000 jobs over the next three years, at a cost of more than $1 billion in redundancy payments. The minister, Senator Alston, has attempted to comfort the thousands of Australians who are to lose their jobs in Telstra by predicting the ease with which they will find employment in the private sector. What an absurdly hollow forecast.

In terms of annual turnover, the industry's rate of increase in Australia has been estimated at around 10 per cent per annum. However, much of the expansion has been in capital intensive areas. The 1994 Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics study, `Communications Futures', concluded that future employment growth in the industry was more likely to occur in the area of content rather than carriage provision. In any way, the minister's optimism does not take into account the fact that the biggest impact of these job losses will be felt in regional centres.
Even the submission to the Senate inquiry from the Liberal government of South Australia acknowledged:
The clearest employment impact of the Telstra privatisation would be in regional centres where Telstra offices are major local employers.

In Queensland, this means places like Townsville, where Telstra's key centre employs 700 people; and Maryborough, Mackay, Cairns and Roma, which all have centres providing directory assistance and emergency service numbers. These regional centres are a significant source of employment for women. In fact, in Roma, the Telstra customer service centre is the biggest industry in town.

In February this year, there were more than 12,500 people employed by Telstra in Queensland, one quarter of whom worked in country areas. What price has the government put on the jobs of these people? Which foreign-owned private telephone company does the minister expect will offer these people jobs in regional centres like Roma, Maryborough and dozens of other towns throughout the country?

This proposal was conceived by the coalition in secret and sprung on the Australian people during the last election campaign. Like so many of this government's proposals, we have heard nothing from the government about what we stand to lose from the sale of this public asset. Nevertheless, it is becoming increasingly clear what the sale of Telstra will really mean to the people of Australia. In short, the jobs of thousands of Australians are being sacrificed in order to make Telstra appear more attractive to potential shareholders.

The opportunity to maximise the social and cultural benefits of the information age will be lost as our communications network is sold into the hands of corporations seeking nothing but profit. I oppose this bill because I believe the price the government has put on Telstra undervalues the network's true worth to this country in terms of regional and cultural development. In effect, it cashes in any chance this country might have to preserve and develop its culture and to create the sort of society that generations of Australians have worked to build.

That is the flow‐on effect of reducing government debt: you improve your credit rating and thus save billions of dollars in interest payments. You also free up taxpayers' money to be used for more worthwhile causes. It is not dead money as we have now with such unwarranted debt.

In the case of the Commonwealth, a debt reduction program will have the advantage, as I said, of freeing up billions of dollars for other budgetary measures. This leads me to the third reason we want this bill to proceed through the Senate. As the Senate is aware, of the estimated $8 billion raised by the sale of Telstra, $1 billion will be used for the establishment of a Natural Heritage Trust. The aim of the trust is to establish a capital base to fund five projects over five years which will result in the much‐needed replenishment of Australia's natural environmental capital. As has been stated in this debate before, the five projects are the natural vegetation initiative, the Murray‐Darling Basin 2001 project, the national reserve system, the national land and water resources audit and the coasts and clean seas initiative. It is a very rare opportunity indeed to have the funds to tackle Australia's worst environmental problems. The alternative—raising debts or taxes—is not something this government is committed to.

One would have thought the environmental movement would have supported our initiatives by supporting the environmental trust. Certainly the rural sector is eager to have the funds to tackle their most serious problem, the Murray‐Darling Basin. There is a very urgent need to restore the health of the Darling and Murray rivers and the lands around those main waterways. The loss of vegetation has contributed to degradation and erosion. In my own state of Victoria, over one‐third of the irrigation areas have become salinised. It is proposed that some $150 million will go towards the Murray‐Darling Basin 2001 project to tackle salinity, erosion, degradation and even blue‐green algae problems.

So the above three reasons for selling Telstra—firstly, that there is a competitive telecommunications industry with the aim of reducing costs to businesses and households; secondly, to reduce government debt so as to free up taxpayers' funds to be used on budget priorities, and, thirdly, to use some of that money, some $1 billion, towards tackling once and for all our worst environmental problems—can hardly be recognised as some coalition ideological bent.

Quite frankly, that argument was put to rest by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kim Beazley, in a speech to the National Press Club in 1994. I will give three prime quotes from his speech so as to lay to rest the ideological debate that has been thrown across this chamber as our main motivation—that there is no sense behind our cause and that we do not have any genuine social or economic reason for selling one‐third of Telstra. Let me put it in context. Mr Beazley, when he was in government, agreed with privatisation when he said:

The primary objective driving the privatisation program is to make Australia an efficient, internationally competitive economy—and that means introducing competition into our enterprises and into our market sectors.
Privatisation fits in with the Government's broader imperative to create jobs—

Of course another benefit of privatisation is that it contributes to the Government budget, helping to reduce debt and providing funds for Government programs. The scale of the asset sales process varies from year to year.

I could not have put it better. If only he had put the proceeds from the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas sales to better use—to reducing debt. However, I quote the Leader of the Opposition to endorse our case. What a difference opposition makes!

Jobs will be lost whether Telstra is privatised or not. Job losses have already been announced. But the telecommunications sector, right across the world, is in a boom period and, with the deregulation of the industry, prospects for the future are quite bright.

That boom has seen a growth in jobs in the telecommunications sector, with some 35,000 jobs having been created since 1992. There has been a reduction in the Telstra work force—I do not have the figure and I do not want to guess at it—but it is believed that, with the growth in the telecommunications industry, those jobs can be transferred to the new entrants. That was confirmed by a telecommunications union representative, Mr Ian McLean—a former president of the Queensland ALP and now a branch secretary of the CEPU—who told the Senate inquiry into Telstra:
I do not think there will be a difference in the number of jobs, but they will not be working for Telstra; they will be working for Skilled Engineering or some other contractor.

It is true that Telstra will suffer a loss of jobs, particularly after 1997, but it is hoped and believed—it is almost assured—that most of those jobs will be transferred to the new competitors, as happened with Optus.

Another major concern that has been raised, and which is of great importance to my party, the National Party, is that the rural sector will suffer in particular from the partial privatisation of Telstra. As I said in my introduction—I do not know how many times we have to say this; I do not think that those opposite will ever believe it—the fact is that the floor is there; the rural sector will not be disadvantaged. Under the Telecommunications Act 1991, service providers are obligated by law to provide a range of services to all Australians on an equitable basis regardless of where they live or conduct their businesses. With the one‐third sale of Telstra this obligation will not be diminished; it will be enhanced. The government has already announced that it will require Telstra to move forward its future mode of operation program by three years to the end of 1998 instead of the 2002 deadline. The escalation of this particular program shows the government's commitment to rural areas in regard to telecommunications.

Rural and regional residents will have access to the integrated services digital network. Some 85 per cent of non‐metropolitan exchanges will be converted to digital by the end of 1997, with the remaining 15 per cent to be upgraded within 12 months.

The universal service guarantee will be put into place to ensure standard telephone services and reasonable access to payphones are available to all Australians regardless of where they live or do business. So I gathered the argument that is put against the bill through reading Senator Schacht's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought I ought to then read the second reading speech in support of this bill. As I go through it, it seems to me that it is a very equivocal speech indeed; that it may well make out a case for the preservation of Telstra in public hands. In the summary at the back on page 18 of the speech, there are a few things I want to quote and comment on. The summary starts:
This Bill is a clear indicator of the Government's intent to do all in its power to deliver on its election promises.
That is absolutely so. It is a correct statement, as there is no doubt that it was an election promise to sell off a third of Telstra. The second paragraph goes on to say:

The Opposition can hardly claim that there is some national interest to be protected by retaining the company in full ownership—the former Prime Minister made clear in June 1994 on national television that there is no essential significance in the ownership of Telstra so long as it was subject to the competitive disciplines of the market.

In addition to that there have been points made in debate—I think Senator O'Chee in one of his excellent speeches made the point—that the Labor Party when in government sold off many of the assets that the Commonwealth owned.

I am not sure that that is an argument. Either it is right to sell Telstra or it is wrong. That has to be judged in terms of the particular object that has been sold off. I think that both you and I, Mr Deputy President, were members of the government party that sold off the Commonwealth Bank. On reflection, I am not sure that that was the best thing we ever did in government. I am sure that the selling off of Telstra would certainly not be the best thing that this parliament will have done if it does sell it off by the end of this term. So I am not sure that quoting what other governments have done is an argument for taking a step now which might be all too drastic.

The third paragraph of the minister's speech on the second reading goes on to talk about the three vital functions that this bill is to perform for all Australians. It talks about the environment and then sets out some issues that need to be tackled. They are, indeed, very important issues. They deal with the rehabilitation of the Murray-Darling; money to be spent on a national land and water resources audit; $100 million for a coast and clean seas initiative. All of these projects are most essential. But all of these are so important that the issue of whether or not this bill goes through should not determine the spending on those particular items. In other words, those items are so important—and this is a point that is made again and again—the money should be spent whether a third of Telstra is sold or not.

The importance of those projects is made out by the minister himself in the second reading speech. The conclusion that the minister, the government and this chamber ought to reach from his comments is that those things should be done—and they should be done straight away, without waiting for the sale of a third of Telstra.
The second reading speech of the minister continues:
One of the most critical justifications for the injection of private equity into our major telecommunications carrier is the need to achieve a more efficient industry and a more efficient Telstra.

I cannot quite follow that, and perhaps senators following me in this debate will explain that to me. I am unable to see that a sale of one-third of Telstra will achieve a more efficient industry and a more efficient Telstra.

The sale of Telstra as a whole might achieve that, on the theories that are going around—and one of those theories is that, if a thing is in private hands, it will be more efficient and better. I do not happen to believe that, but that is the argument put, and it has been put here. But from that we then reach the conclusion that the sale of a third of Telstra will achieve that—but the sale of a third of Telstra will not be the privatisation of Telstra. The promise or the trouble is—and, indeed, Senator Alston got himself into trouble for suggesting to the contrary—that only a third of Telstra is being sold. So how can this argument work—that is, that if there is an injection of private equity into this telecommunication there will be a more efficient industry and a more efficient Telstra. It just does not follow.
The next issue I want to talk about is this: the second reading speech then continues:

The onus is on those who have so far been content to hide behind outdated ideological defences of the public sector, to demonstrate that business as usual is going to be anything other than a recipe for declining competitiveness for our major carrier and inferior consumer outcomes for all Australians.

That is one of the problems about this debate—that the onus is put on those on whom it should not be put. The onus is upon those who are to sell this. The people who allege that something ought to be done, who say that a particular step ought to be taken, ought to be the ones to show that that is so. I see in the gallery here a very eminent lawyer from Victoria, Mr David McKenna, who practises extensively in the criminal area. He will tell you how this idea of onus ought to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had much to do with him, Senator?
—I have had a lot to do with him, because I learned a lot—
—Have you been one of his clients?
—One of his clients I have not been. But if I were in need of a criminal lawyer, I would certainly go to Mr David McKenna.

SPEECH.PARA: But in the event, the point is this: the whole debate in this area has gone forward on the basis that the onus is on those who want to maintain the status quo—and the status quo, as I will come to later on in this speech, is pretty good; the minister admits that the status quo is pretty good. But it has been said that the onus should be on those who want to preserve the present situation—and the present situation is that a very big dividend is being returned to the Commonwealth; that this is the highest taxed company in Australia which contributes more to the public coffers than any other company in Australia, and that is in the second reading speech.

The onus ought to be on the government to show that a company which is producing so much for Australia should be sold. To come in here and state in the second reading speech that the onus is upon those who want to resist this, and that is the end of the argument, is just nonsense. It is not in accordance with the great philosophies and great traditions with which Senator MacGibbon, Senator O'Chee and Senator Parer have grown up in that great Liberal tradition. They would understand that that is absolutely wrong. Madam President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being nearly 3.45 p.m., I propose the question:

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to address a number of issues that seem to have been the subject of some attention in the other place yesterday during question time, particularly with respect to the involvement of many of the Labor members and senators with their trade unions. Being a senator who has a very long history in the trade union movement arising initially out of the three years I spent on sites working as a labour, it is quite interesting that this very fact now is being used by this government to try to throw back in Labor's face the issue of conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is quite astounding that the government has been so desperate to use this issue as the one they bring forward in a petty attempt at defence of the issue of shares they are confronting in both houses of parliament. I think this attempt to deflect the attention from them and to bring in the issue of union membership and former union representation of many of the Labor senators shows just how removed this government is from working people in this country. You need only look at the role of unions in Australia and the work and commitment that has been shown throughout all of those organisations in the advancement of the interests and the rights and conditions of employment of working people to understand and appreciate the value of the union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rally at Parliament House?

—It is interesting to see that senators from across the floor, on the government side, continually dig up the rally that occurred here on 19 August as an issue to deflect focus from the problem at hand. The problem at hand is that we have a government with frontbenchers who have been exposed as having a conflict of interest as a result of their shareholdings.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue highlights the great distinctions that exist between Labor representatives and Liberal government representatives. The distinction is that we on the Labor side do represent working people. The fact that many of us have a trade union background reinforces the fact that we have been working in our various roles—as on‐site shop stewards, as delegates or as health and safety representatives, which is where I started off—and have come into this place to further those interests.

It is very telling that this distinction comes into play when we are dealing with the bunch of very wealthy people on the government front bench. This distinction and the highlighting of this distinction as a result of this debate I think really define the role of the two major parties into the future. There are not only major differences with respect to policy but there are major differences with respect to where we are coming from.

I know where I am coming from and what I bring to this place. It is unique in a number of ways in terms of my background as a labourer here in Canberra. The strength of this place is that it brings together people with a wide variety of experiences. I, for one, would like to put in my view about the importance of people with a union background—people with a background in representing the real interests of working people in this country—being in this place, speaking their mind and pursuing the aspirations of working people generally.

Union members right around the country and all those workers who are not members of a union but who have benefited from the gains of the trade union movement over a long period of time recognise the role that the unions have played. It is an association that I am extremely proud to be part of. The value and importance of transferring that experience and that commitment to improving the lot of working people to this place is something that no-one can deny has intrinsic value in the political process in this country. For this government to use it as a political stick exposes it as being the most shallow, contemptuous frontbench you could possibly imagine.

The union movement has a very proud tradition in this country. The union movement has improved this country's workplace conditions and the whole philosophy of having a fair go in the workplace. It has ensured that there is some level of commitment to a degree of occupational health and safety, which means you can go into a workplace and come out of it in the same condition. That is something that is not often replicated in many comparable Western democracies. It is something that sets us apart. It is part of the whole debate about workplace relations, which we are looking at at the moment.

There is no doubt that what we are seeing on the agenda with the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is something that will disassociate Australian workers and their ability to fight for their rights and to maintain their working conditions and their conditions of employment. The workplace relations bill epitomises the very paranoia and the very platform that this government came into office on. I recall very clearly the first headline that came out early on in Howard's ascendancy to the leadership

BREAK.PARA: of the Liberal Party. It was about how he was going to trash the unions.

When he says he is going to trash the unions, he is saying that he is going to trash the workers. He is going to go after their wages and conditions. That is what he is saying. When he talks about individual choice, he is talking about isolation. That isolation of workers and their inability to defend themselves ultimately lead to exploitation and the downgrading of their conditions of employment.

So when I see this government come in with an agenda like that contained in the workplace relations bill and I see headlines that really in the first instance declare where Howard is coming from, it is a very telling moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr Howard, Senator.

—It is very telling to know that Mr Howard has an agenda of industrial relations. His agenda is to break the unions and to reduce the conditions of workers. He thinks that misguided philosophy and ideology will somehow be the solution to this country's problems. I refute that completely. I do not believe that that conservative ideology has any place in this country. That is the challenge before Labor from hereon in.

BREAK.PARA: The more Mr Howard and his ministers focus on his anti-union beliefs and rant and rave—such as Mr Reith, who ranted and raved in the other place yesterday during question time—the more they expose themselves as being a one-eyed government with no vision, with no broad agenda and with no regard to the social values that have evolved in this country over the last century and that are intrinsically based in our industrial relations system. That includes the involvement of the union movement and the involvement, therefore, of workers in that process and the ability of those workers to maintain some say in what their lives are like and the standards and conditions under which they work.
